(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1991
1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia Justice Kennedy, and
Justice Souter.
The Chief Justice said:
"I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 1990 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now closed
and that the October 1991 Term is now convened. Today's orders of the
Court have been certified by the Chief Justice, filed with the Clerk, and
will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 90-1639. United States, Petitioner v. Robert Widdowson, Bruce
Bachman and Michael Whitely. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Touby v. United States, 500 U. S.
(1991).
No. 90–1853. Nationwide Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Howing
Company and Douglas McLellan. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Virginia Bankshares, Inc. v. Sand-
berg, 501 U. S. — (1991).
-
No. 90-1864. New York State Department of Health, Petitioner v.
Joanna Andrulonis, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
for further consideration in light of United States v. Gaubert, 499 U. S.
(1991).
No. 90–1936. Parker Solvents Company, Inc., Petitioner v. Royal In-
surance Companies of America, formerly Royal Globe Insurance Co. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in
light of Salve Regina College v. Russell, 499 U. S. — (1991).

2
MONDAY, OCTOBER 7. 1991
No. 90-7574. Stephen Buckley, Petitioner v. Michael Fitzsimmons,
et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of Burns v. Reed, 500 U. S. ——— (1991).
No. 90-8219. Hurley Richard, et al., Petitioners v. Louis W. Sulli-
van, Secretary of Health and Human Services. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the
petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Melkonyan v. Sulli-
van, 501 U. S. - (1991).
-
No. 91-162. Joyce Inaba, et al., Petitioners v. Rosemary Soong, et
al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Hawaii.
The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated
and the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Hawaii for further
consideration in light of Siegert v. Gilley, 500 U. S. — (1991).
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Cynthia Alessi, etc., Petitioner v. Pennsylvania, et al. The
motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of
indigency executed by petitioner is granted.
No.
-
Kevin Burke, Petitioner v. Howard L. Beyer, Superin-
tendent, New Jersey State Prison, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk
to docket an appeal from the United States District Court for the Dis-
trict of New Jersey is denied.
-
No. . Talakkottur R. David, Petitioner v. AT&T, et al. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-
time is denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.
No. . In Re J.S. The motion for leave to file a petition for a writ
of certiorari under seal, or alternatively with portions deleted, is
denied.
-.
No. Arthur H. Lawrence, Petitioner v. California. The motion
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency
executed by petitioner is denied.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 7. 1991
3
No. In the Matter of the Application of Alfred Bruce Shapiro
for Readmission to the Bar of this Court. The application for readmis-
sion to the Bar of this Court presented to Justice Scalia and by him re-
ferred to the Court is denied.
No. A-195. Southern Life and Health Insurance Company and Rich-
ard Perry, Applicant v. Lucy R. Turner. The application for a stay ad-
dressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-1006. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thuryo A. Sneed. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1010. In the Matter of George J. Bolton. George J. Bolton, of
North Miami Beach, Florida, having requested to resign as a member
of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this Court. The
Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on June 17, 1991, is hereby
discharged.
No. D-1019. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Henry Turner.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1020. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alphonse Della-Donna.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1022. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stanley Bernard Gel-
man. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1027. In the Matter of Disbarment of Burt H. Sagen. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for approval of fees and expenses is
granted and the River Master is awarded $10,705.20 for the period
April 1 through June 30, 1991, to be paid equally by the parties. The
motion of New Mexico to review the River Master's final report for
Water Year 1990 is denied.
No. 90–209. California, Petitioner v. Ignacio Cambrax Salgado. The
motion of respondent to retax costs is denied.
No. 90–918. Christine Franklin, Petitioner v. Gwinnett County Pub-
lic Schools and William Prescott. The motion of petitioner to dispense
with printing the joint appendix is granted. The motion of the Solicitor
General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and
for divided argument is granted.
No. 90-1205. United States, Petitioner v. Ray Mabus, Governor of
Mississippi, et al.; and
No. 90-6588. Jake Ayers, et al., Petitioners v. Ray Mabus, Governor
of Mississippi, et al. The motion of Charles E. “Buddy” Roemer III,

4
MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1991
Governor of the State of Louisiana, et al. for leave to file a brief as
amici curiae is granted. The motion of Board of Trustees of the Univer-
sity of Alabama for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 90-1271. Norfolk and Western Railway Company, Petitioner v.
Olen Roberson, et al. The motion of respondents for attorneys' fees is
denied without prejudice to refiling in the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fourth Circuit.
No. 90-1390. General Motors Corporation, et al. Petitioners v. Evert
Romein, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
denied.
No. 90-1596. F. Dale Robertson, Chief, United States Forest Serv-
ice, et al., Petitioners v. Seattle Audubon Society, et al. The motion of
Pacific Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted.
No. 90-1739. Fuqua Industries, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Ruth F.
Jandrucko. The motion of respondent for damages is denied.
No. 90-1832. Walter Pestrak, Petitioner v. Ohio Elections Commis-
sion, et al.; and
No. 91–9. Ohio Elections Commission, et al., Petitioners v. Walter
Pestrak. The motion of the parties to defer consideration of the peti-
tions for writs of certiorari is granted for sixty days.
No. 90-1846. George F. Denton, Director of Corrections of Califor-
nia, et al., Petitioners v. Mike Hernandez. The motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
No. 90-1861. Greenville Public School District, et al., Petitioners v.
Western Line Consolidated School District, et al. The Solicitor General
is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 90-1897. United Artists Communications, Inc., et al., Petition-
ers v. The Movie 1 & 2. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 90-1918. Kraft General Foods, Inc., Petitioner v. Iowa Depart-
ment of Revenue and Finance. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 90–1977. Johnny Dupree, et al., Appellants v. Mike Moore, At-
torney General of Mississippi, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to
file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1991
5
No. 91-4. International Union of Operating Engineers Local No. 12,
AFL-CIO, Petitioner v. Carroll Wilson, et al. The Solicitor General is
invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the United
States.
No. 90-7225. In Re John Robert Demos, Jr., Petitioner. The motion
of petitioner for reconsideration of denial of leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied.
No. 91-5050. J. David Golub, Petitioner v. University of Chicago, et
al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 28, 1991, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U. S. 928 (1983), I would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
Justice Blackmun took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 91-5219. Edward J. Brennan, Jr., Petitioner v. Ann Marie Bren-
nan. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 28, 1991, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.
No. 91-5431. Ernestine Forrest, Petitioner v. Occidental Petroleum
Corporation, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until October 28, 1991,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 90-1599. United States, Petitioner v. Frank Dennis Felix. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit granted.
No. 91-42. United States, Petitioner v. Therese A. Burke, Cynthia
R. Center, and Linda G. Gibbs. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted.

6
MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1991
No. 91-72. Federal Trade Commission, Petitioner v. Ticor Title In-
surance Company, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
No. 91-126. Howard Wyatt, Petitioner v. Bill Cole and John Rob-
bins, II. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 91-159. William Barnhill, Petitioner v. Elliot Johnson, Trustee.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit granted.
No. 91-164. United States, Petitioner v. Thompson/Center Arms
Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted.
No. 90-1419. National Railroad Passenger Corporation, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Boston and Maine Corporation, et al.; and
No. 90-1769. Interstate Commerce Commission and United States,
Petitioners v. Boston and Maine Corporation, et al. Petitions for writs
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of one
hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 90-1745. United States, Petitioner v. Richard Wilson. The mo-
tion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit granted.
No. 90-1859. J. C. Keeney, Superintendent, Oregon State Peniten-
tiary, Petitioner v. Jose Tamayo-Reyes. The motion of respondent for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
granted.
No. 90-1912. Stephanie Nordlinger, Petitioner v. Kenneth Hahn, in
His Capacity as Tax Assessor for Los Angeles County, et al. The mo-
tion of William K. Rentz for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of
California, Second Appellate District, granted.
No. 90-8466. David Riggins, Petitioner v. Nevada. The motion of pe-
titioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nevada granted.
No. 91–119. Wisconsin Department of Revenue, Petitioner v. Wil-
liam Wrigley, Jr., Co. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Wisconsin granted. The case is set for oral argument in tan-
dem with No. 91-194, Quill Corp. v. North Dakota.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 7. 1991
7
No. 91–194. Quill Corporation, Petitioner v. North Dakota by and
through its Tax Commissioner, Heidi Heitkamp. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of North Dakota granted limited to
Question 1 presented by the petition. The case is set for oral argument
in tandem with No. 91-119, Wisconsin Department of Revenue v. Wil-
liam Wrigley, Jr., Co.

No. 90-1620. Robert Pearson, et al., Petitioners v. United States.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1991
No. 90-1623. S. E. Johnson Company, et al., Petitioners v. Arthur S.
Langenderfer, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United

117
The Chief Justice said:
"Before calling the first case for argument this morning, it is appro-
priate for us to note that today, for the first time in twenty-four years,
a Term of the Court commences without our colleague Justice Thurgood
Marshall sitting beside us on the bench. Following his retirement this
summer his colleagues on the Court joined in sending him a letter which
reads as follows:
September 12, 1991
Dear Thurgood,
Your decision to retire from the Court brings a sense of sorrow to all
of us. For twenty-four years you have been a colleague, and for twenty-
four years you have had an important voice in the shaping of the deci-

118
MONDAY, OCTOBER 7. 1991
sional law of this Court. We will miss your counsel in our future delib-
erations, and will likewise miss the innumerable "tall tales" with which
you delighted us.
Everyone who sits on the Supreme Court will be remembered in the
history of American constitutional law, but you are unique in having
made major contributions to that law before becoming a member of the
Court. Your role in the battle for equal treatment of the races would
entitle you to a prominent place in that history had you never ascended
the bench at all. You leave behind you landmarks from your career as a
lawyer, as well as from your career as a judge.
We bid you farewell from our common labors, but look forward to your
continued society off the bench. We trust that retirement at this time
will help you regain the good health which is our wish for you.
Affectionately,
William H. Rehnquist
Byron R. White
Harry A. Blackmun
John Paul Stevens
Sandra O'Connor
Antonin Scalia
Anthony M. Kennedy
David H. Souter."
Justice Marshall said:
"Dear Colleagues,
Thank you for your gracious letter. As I read it, I was reminded of the
wonderful times we have spent together both personally and profes-
sionally over the years. It has been a great honor for me to serve on
the Court, and I am saddened that I must now give up the daily fare-
the oral arguments, the Conference discussions, the opinions and dis-
sents that has provided me such enormous intellectual and emotional
satisfaction for 24 years.
More than that, though, I am saddened that I will no longer have the
opportunity to enjoy regular contact and communications with all of
you. Your warmth and collegiality have been of great encouragement
to me; I will miss that - and all of you-deeply.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 7. 1991
119
Although I will not take part in the work ahead, I am hopeful the
Court will meet the upcoming challenges, and I am grateful for the time
we have spent together. Because of the bonds we have formed, I rest
assured that though my active service on the Court ends, our ties of
friendship hold fast.
Affectionately,
Thurgood."

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and
Justice Souter.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 90-1713. United States, Petitioner v. Alejandro Garcia Ibarra.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91–269. Donald L. Helling, et al., Petitioners v. William McKin-
ney. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Wilson v. Seiter, 501 U.S. (1991). Justice Black-
mun and Justice Stevens would deny certiorari.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-142. John S. Trinsey, Jr., Applicant v. Pennsylvania, et al.
The application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and referred to
the Court is denied.
No. D-1005. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard Kelly. The mo-
tion to defer consideration is denied. Disbarment order entered.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
Order amending March 28, 1988, order appointing River Master: It is
ordered that Neil S. Grigg be and he hereby is appointed River Master
of the Pecos River for the purpose of performing the duties set forth in
the Amended Decree of March 28, 1988. It is further ordered that the
River Master shall have the power and authority to subpoena informa-

126
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1991
tion or data, compiled in reasonable usable form, which he deems neces-
sary or desirable for the proper and efficient performance of his duties.
It is further ordered that the River Master is allowed his necessary ex-
penses, including the cost of competent legal advice deemed by him to
be necessary to carry out his duties, as well as reasonable fees for his
services, statements for which shall be submitted quarterly to the
Court for its approval. Upon Court approval, such statements will be
paid by the State of New Mexico and the State of Texas. It is further
ordered that if the position of the River Master becomes vacant during
a recess of the Court, the Chief Justice shall have authority to make a
new designation which shall have the same effect as if originally made
by the Court.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware v. State of New York. The mo-
tion of Oregon for leave to intervene and adopt complaint is referred to
the Special Master.
No. 90-1205. United States, Petitioner v. Ray Mabus, Governor of
Mississippi, et al.; and
No. 90-6588. Jake Ayers, et al., Petitioners v. Ray Mabus, Governor
of Mississippi, et al. The motion of respondents to strike amicus curiae
brief of Jackson State University is denied.

amici curiae is granted.

MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1991
155
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and
Justice Souter.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 91-311. Raymond Mireles, Petitioner v. Howard Waco. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment
reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Scalia with whom Justice Kennedy joins.
ORDERS IN Pending Cases
No. A-150. Barbara J. Turner, Applicant v. Barbara J. Runser, et al.
The application for stay addressed to Justice White and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-1040. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alex A. Gaynes. It is
ordered that Alex A. Gaynes, of Tucson, Arizona, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1041. In the Matter of Disbarment of Justin Norbert Scharf.
It is ordered that Justin Norbert Scharf, of Hagerstown, Maryland, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1042. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald H. McLellan, Jr.
It is ordered that Donald H. McLellan, Jr., of Columbia, South Caro-
lina, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule.
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

156
MONDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1991
No. 90-1038. Thomas Cipollone, Individually and as Executor of the
Estate of Rose D. Cipollone, Petitioner v. Liggett Group, Inc., et al.
This case is restored to the calendar for reargument.
No. 90-1279. Myra Jo Collins, Petitioner v. City of Harker Heights,
Texas. The motion of petitioner to supplement the record is granted.
No. 91–10. Spectrum Sports, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Shirley
McQuillan, et vir, dba Sorboturf Enterprises; and
No. 91-32. Sorbothane, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Shirley McQuillan,
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in these cases ex-
pressing the views of the United States.
No. 91-5785. Ralph A. Wood, Petitioner v. Metropolitan Life Insur-
ance Company. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until November 12, 1991,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), I would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 90-8370. Teofilo Medina, Jr., Petitioner v. California. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The
petition for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of California is
granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition.

writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Texas, Second District,
denied.

Linda Lalli Stark

Elizabeth Marion Young
Linda Elizabeth Zappi
Justice White said:
Buffalo, NY
Poughkeepsie,
NY
"On Thursday, October 17th, Natalie Cornell Rehnquist, the wife of
Chief Justice William Rehnquist, died of cancer at the National Insti-
tutes of Health.
Nan, as she was known, was determined to live her life to the fullest
even as she battled her long illness. She was always cheerful and in-
credibly uncomplaining, always thoughtful of other people. Her coura-
geous struggle inspired the love and admiration of everyone who knew
her. She will be sorely missed.
Nan was born in San Diego, was graduated from Stanford, and after
her marriage in 1953, lived with her husband in Phoenix until they
moved to Washington in 1969. Here, she worked tirelessly and lovingly
at the Lutheran Home for the Aged as President of the Home's Auxil-
iary and for 8 years on the staff as director of volunteer service.
Whatever Nan was involved in, she was involved wholeheartedly,
whether it was the Lutheran Home, her International Neighbors Club,
her considerable duties as the wife of the Chief Justice, or as the won-
derful mother of their three children. She truly cared.
Also, one cannot omit mentioning her outstanding talents as a gour-
met cook and expert in all types of sewing and needlework. She was as
gifted as she was loving. We are all fortunate to have known her.
As a mark of our sorrow and of our affection for her and for our
brother, the Chief Justice, and for his family, the Journal of Court will
record that the adjournment of this Court today is in honor of Natalie
Rehnquist, her life, and her memory."

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 30, 1991
169
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-267. American Newspaper Publishers Association, et al., Ap-
plicants v. United States, et al. The application for stay presented to
the Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice
O'Connor took no part in the consideration or decision of this application.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1991
171
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and
Justice Souter.
The Chief Justice said:
"This special sitting of the Court is held today to receive the commis-
sion of the newly appointed Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of
the United States, Clarence Thomas. The Court now recognizes the
Acting Attorney General of the United States, William Barr."
The Acting Attorney General said:
"Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court, I have the commis-
sion which has been issued to the Honorable Clarence Thomas as an As-
sociate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States. The commis-
sion has been duly signed by the President of the United States and
attested by me as the Acting Attorney General of the United States. I
move that the Clerk read the commission and that it be made a part of
the permanent records of this Court."
The Chief Justice said:
"Thank you Mr. Barr. Your motion is granted. Mr. Clerk, will you
please read the Commission?"
The Clerk then read the commission as follows:
"George Bush, President of the United States of America,
"To all who shall see these Presents, Greeting:
"Know Ye; That reposing special trust and confidence in the Wisdom,
Uprightness, and Learning of Clarence Thomas, of Georgia, I have
nominated, and, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, do
appoint him an Associate Justice of the United States and do authorize
and empower him to execute and fulfill the duties of that Office accord-
ing to the Constitution and Laws of the said United States, and to have
and to hold the said Office, with all the powers, privileges, and emolu-
ments to the same of right appertaining, unto Him, the said Clarence
Thomas, during his good behavior.
"In testimony whereof, I have caused these Letters to be made pat-
ent and the seal of the Department of Justice to be hereunto affixed.
"Done at the City of Washington, this sixteenth day of October, in
the year of our Lord one thousand nine hundred and ninety-one, and of
the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and
sixteenth.
"By the President: George Bush.

172
FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 1. 1991
"William P. Barr, Acting Attorney General."
The Chief Justice said:
"I now ask the Chief Deputy Clerk of the Court to escort Justice
Thomas to the bench."
The Chief Justice said:
"Justice Thomas, are you prepared to take the oath?"
Justice Thomas said:
"I am."
The oath of office was then administered by the Chief Justice and
Justice Thomas repeated the oath after him as follows:
"I, Clarence Thomas, do solemnly swear that I will administer justice
without respect to person, and do equal right to the poor and to the
rich, and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and perform all
the duties incumbent upon me as Associate Justice of the Supreme
Court of the United States under the Constitution and laws of the
United States. So help me God."
The Chief Justice said:
"Justice Thomas, on behalf of all the members of the Court, it is a
pleasure to extend to you a very warm welcome as an Associate Justice
of this Court and to wish for you a long and happy career in our common
calling."
The Chief Justice said:
"Effective with the appointment of Justice Thomas, an order has
been entered by the Court today revising the assignment of the Circuit
Justices as follows:
District of Columbia, Fourth and Federal Circuits: The Chief Justice
First and Third Circuits: Justice Souter
Second Circuit: Justice Thomas
Fifth Circuit: Justice Scalia
Sixth and Seventh Circuits: Justice Stevens
Eighth Circuit: Justice Blackmun
Ninth Circuit: Justice O'Connor
Tenth Circuit: Justice White
Eleventh Circuit: Justice Kennedy
Adjourned until Monday, November 4, 1991, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1991
173
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."

cordingly, the petitioners are allowed until November 25, 1991, within

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1991
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38 and to submit peti-
tions in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice
Blackmun joins. Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration or de-
cision of these motions.
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-337. Robert J. Sheheen, Speaker of the House of Represent-
atives of South Carolina, etc., Appellant v. Joe Tisdale, et al. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the District of South Caro-
lina. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United
States District Court for the District of South Carolina with instruc-
tions to dismiss the appeal as moot. United States v. Munsingwear,
Inc., 340 U.S. 36 (1950).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-984. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gene Flinn. The motion
for reinstatement is denied.

No. D-1043. In the Matter of Disbarment of Burnett Merrell Frazer,
Jr. It is ordered that Burnett Merrell Frazer, Jr., of Austin, Texas, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1044. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lawrence Anthony
Weisensee. It is ordered that Lawrence Anthony Weisensee, of Duluth,
Georgia, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1045. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald Marvin Cohen.
It is ordered that Ronald Marvin Cohen, of Encino, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-

turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should

No. D-1046. In the Matter of Disbarment of Andrew James Jenkins.

suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

counsel for the respondent in this case.
No. 91-5759. Dana Nolan Mattiza, Petitioner v. Texas. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner
is allowed until November 25, 1991, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of cer-

176
MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1991
tiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.

ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Bren-
nan (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit during the period of No-
vember 22, 1991, and for such time as may be required to complete un-
finished business, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 294(a), is ordered entered
on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 295.

An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Mar-
shall (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Federal Circuit during the period of November 8, 1991,
and for such time as may be required to complete unfinished business,
pursuant to 28 U. S. C. Sec. 294(a), is ordered entered on the minutes
of this Court, pursuant to 28 U. S. C. Sec. 295.

CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 91-6337. G. W. Green, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Director,
Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant
the application for a stay of execution of sentence of death.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 12. 1991
215
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 91–434. Hollis Watkins, et al., Appellants v. Ray Mabus, Gover-
nor of Mississippi, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the Southern District of Mississippi. The judgment is affirmed ex-
cept with respect to appellants' claim that the preclearance require-
ments of Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act apply to the changes in the
absentee ballot procedures adopted for the September 17 election or-
dered by the district court. The completion of the September 17 elec-
tion has rendered this claim moot with regard to the relief sought, i.e.,
an order enjoining the September 17 election for failure to comply with
preclearance requirements. Accordingly, we vacate that portion of the
judgment below with instructions to dismiss the relevant part of the
complaint. Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, 492 U. S. 490,
512-513 (1989); United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U.S. 36, 39-40
(1950). Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would note probable ju-
risdiction and set the case for oral argument.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-5518. Hamza Al Kashif, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Tenth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of the
position presently asserted by the Solicitor General in his brief for the
United States filed October 21, 1991.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-224. Lieu B. Hoang, Applicant v. Stephen M. Sims, et al. The
application for leave to file a petition for a writ of certiorari in excess of

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1991
the page limitations and an oversized appendix addressed to the Chief

No. D-1028. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Anthony Weber,
Jr. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1047. In the Matter of Disbarment of Al Katz. It is ordered
that Al Katz, of Buffalo, New York, be suspended from the practice of
law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within forty days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1048. In the Matter of Disbarment of Pasquale G. Cannavino.
It is ordered that Pasquale G. Cannavino, of Newport News, Virginia,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

tion for appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Michael
Pescetta, Esquire, of San Francisco, California, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the petitioner in this case.

ers v. Illinois Commerce Commission, et al. The Solicitor General is in-

States.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-1031. In the Matter of Disbarment of E. Gene Wade. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-1032. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marvin A. Brill. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-1049. In the Matter of Disbarment of Luis Oscar Beltre. It is
ordered that Luis Oscar Beltre, of Paramus, New Jersey, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1050. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Friedman. It is
ordered that Michael Friedman, of Los Alamitos, California, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1051. In the Matter of Disbarment of Luis F. Urroz. It is or-
dered that Luis F. Urroz, of San Francisco, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1052. In the Matter of Disbarment of Theodore Andrew
Cavacos. It is ordered that Theodore Andrew Cavacos, of Baltimore,
Maryland, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that
a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1053. In the Matter of Disbarment of James J. Michalek. It is
ordered that James J. Michalek, of Lackawanna, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1991
255
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice. Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-379. James A. Collins, Director, Texas Department of Crimi-
nal Justice, Institutional Division, Applicant v. Justin Lee May. The
application of the Attorney General of Texas for an order to vacate the
stay of execution of sentence of death entered by the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit presented to Justice Scalia and
by him referred to the Court is denied. The Chief Justice, Justice
Scalia, and Justice Thomas would grant the application to vacate the
stay.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1991
257
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 90-857. Marc Gilbert Doggett, Petitioner v. United States. The
case is restored to the calendar for reargument. Counsel are directed to
submit supplemental briefs on the question whether the history of the
Speedy Trial Clause of the Sixth Amendment supports the view that
the clause protects a right of citizens to repose, free from the fear of
secret or unknown indictments for past crimes, independent of any in-
terest in preventing lengthy pretrial incarceration or prejudice to the
case of a criminal defendant. Justice Thomas took no part in the consid-
eration or decision of this order.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 90–1604. Dan Morales, Attorney General of Texas, Petitioner v.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.
No. 91-571. Robert J. Taylor, Trustee, Petitioner v. Freeland &
Kronz, Wendell G. Freeland and Richard F. Kronz. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
granted.
No. 91-594. American National Red Cross, Petitioner v. S.G. and
A.E. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the First Circuit granted.
No. 91-615. Allied-Signal, Inc., as successor-in-interest to The
Bendix Corporation, Petitioner v. Director, Division of Taxation. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Jersey granted.
No. 91-611. Keyton E. Barker and Pauline Barker, et al., Petitioners
v. Kansas, et al. The motion of Retired Officers Association for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Kansas granted.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 2. 1991
259
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice. Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-627. Arizona, Petitioner v. Voatress Mullen, Jr. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division One.
The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of Arizona,
Division One, for further consideration in light of Florida v. Bostick,
501 U.S. (1991).
-

General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of the

No. 91–792. Willis Sargent, Warden, Petitioner v. Wilburn A. Hen-
derson. The application for stay addressed to Justice O'Connor and re-

No. 91-836. Union Bank of Switzerland, Petitioner v. United States.
The application for stay of the mandate of the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit presented to Justice Kennedy and by
him referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition by this
Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall con-
tinue pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.
No. 91-5947. Juan C. De Caceres, Petitioner v. David A. Scholl. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until December 23, 1991, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald
Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.
No. 91–6057. Robert Schulz, Petitioner v. Washington County, et al.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is de-
nied. Petitioner is allowed until December 23, 1991, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), I would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.
No. 91–6061. Francis Osei-Afriyie, Petitioner v. Medical College of
Pennsylvania, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until December 23,
1991, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and
to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1991
289
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice, Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 90-6352. Diane Griffin, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun concurring in the judgment. Justice Thomas took no part in
the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 90-913. Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System of
the United States, Petitioner v. MCorp Financial, Inc., et al.; and
No. 90-914. MCorp, et al., Petitioners v. Board of Governors of the
Federal Reserve System of the United States. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The judgment
is affirmed in part, reversed in part and the cases are remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Justice Thomas took no part
in the consideration or decision of these cases.

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1991
291
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 90-584. Southwest Marine, Inc., Petitioner v. Byron Gizoni. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Justice Thomas
took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 90-967. Guy Wooddell, Jr., Petitioner v. International Brother-
hood of Electrical Workers, Local 71, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
White. Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
No. 90-1074. Wayne Estelle, Warden, Petitioner v. Mark Owen
McGuire. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice Ste-
vens join. Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision
of this case.
No. 90-1102. Robert E. Gibson, Petitioner v. Florida Bar, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. The writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvidently
granted. Opinion per curiam.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,

"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Kurtis B. Borre, Petitioner v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is
denied.
No. A-372. Daniel Vasquez, Warden, Applicant v. Robert Alton
Harris. The application to vacate the order of the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granting a stay of mandate, presented
to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court, is denied.
No. 90-1745. United States, Petitioner v. Richard Wilson. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix
is granted.
No. 90-1846. George F. Denton, Director of Corrections of Califor-
nia, et al., Petitioners v. Mike Hernandez. The motion of petitioners to
dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 90–1859. J. C. Keeney, Superintendent, Oregon State Peniten-
tiary, Petitioner v. Jose Tamayo-Reyes. The motion of Criminal Justice
Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 91-142. Tidewater Marine Service, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Lloyd W. Aubry, Jr., et al.; and
No. 91-349. Pacific Merchant Shipping Association, et al., Petition-
ers v. Lloyd W. Aubry, Jr., Labor Commissioner, Division of Labor
Standards Enforcement, Department of Industrial Relations of Califor-
nia. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in these cases express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 91-356. Mead Corporation, Petitioner v. B. E. Tilley, et al. The
Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the
views of the United States.
No. 91-610. Local 144 Nursing Home Pension Fund, et al., Petition-
ers v. Nicholas Demisay, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1991
No. 91-5450. James Ernest Hitchcock, Petitioner v. Florida. The re-
spondent is requested to file a response to the petition for rehearing
within thirty days.
No. 91–6109. E. N. Gilbertson, Petitioner v. Robert Graham, et al.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is de-
nied. Petitioner is allowed until December 30, 1991, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

"The Court now recognizes the Solicitor General, Mr. Kenneth
Starr."
Mr. Solicitor General Kenneth Starr said:
"Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, I have the honor to
present to the Court the seventy-seventh Attorney General of the
United States, the Honorable William Pelham Barr of Virginia."

MONDAY, DECEMBER 9.1991
The Chief Justice said:
305
"Mr. Attorney General, on behalf of the Court I welcome you as the
chief law officer of the government and as an officer of this Court. We
welcome you to the performance of the very important duties which will
rest upon you by virtue of your office. Your commission as Attorney
General of the United States will be placed in the records of the Court.
and we wish you well in your new office."
Attorney General William Barr said:
"Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice."

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 90-1141. Rafeh-Rafie Ardestani, Petitioner v. Immigration and
Naturalization Service. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom
Justice Stevens joins. Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration
or decision of this case.
No. 90-1059. Simon & Schuster, Inc., Petitioner v. Members of the
New York State Crime Victims Board, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment. Justice
Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

MONDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1991
311
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Scalia, Jus-
tice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 90-1440. Brian V. Hunter and Jeffrey Jordan, Petitioners v.
James V. Bryant, Jr. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for a writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is reversed and the case is re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Opinion by Justice
Scalia concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy. Justice Thomas took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-350. Luther Langford Taylor, Petitioner v. United States.
The application for bond pending appeal addressed to Justice Scalia and
referred to the Court is denied.

Jr. Disbarment order entered.

quardt. It is ordered that Philip Walter Marquardt, of Phoenix, Ari-
zona, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

It is ordered that Todd Eric Blumenfeld, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Kenneth L. Waldron, of Jackson, Missouri, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-

No. 91-860. United States Department of Commerce, et al., Appel-
lants v. Montana, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Montana. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.
The motion of appellees for expedited briefing schedule and oral argu-
ment is granted. The opening brief of appellants is to be filed with the
Clerk on or before January 15, 1992. The brief of appellees is to be filed
with the Clerk on or before February 12, 1992. The reply brief of appel-
lants is to be filed with the Clerk on or before February 21, 1992. The
case is set for oral argument during the Session beginning February 24,
1992.

OPINIONS
No. 90-889. William "Sky" King, Petitioner v. St. Vincent's Hospital.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Justice Thomas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 90-848. Kenneth Hilton, Petitioner v. South Carolina Public
Railways Commission. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
South Carolina. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Justice Blackmun concurs in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice
Scalia joins. Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of this case.
No. 90-747. United States Department of State, Petitioner v. Mi-
chael D. Ray, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens and an-
nounced by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in
part and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Kennedy joins.
Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
case.
No. 90-1090. Immigration and Naturalization Service, et al., Peti-
tioners v. National Center for Immigrants' Rights, Inc., et al. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Stevens and announced by the Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1991
327
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-442. James A. Collins, Director, Texas Department of Crimi-
nal Justice, Institutional Division, Applicant v. David Lee Holland. The
application of the Attorney General of Texas for an order to vacate the
stay of execution of sentence of death entered by the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Scalia took no part
in the consideration or decision of this application.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1991
329
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91–542. Ellis B. Wright, Jr., Warden and Mary Sue Terry, At-
torney General of Virginia, Petitioners v. Frank Robert West, Jr. The
order of December 16, 1991, granting the petition for a writ of certio-
rari, is amended as follows: The motion of respondent for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted. In addition to the questions presented by the petition, the
parties are requested to brief and argue the following question: In
determining whether to grant a petition for a writ of habeas corpus by a
person in custody pursuant to the judgment of a state court, should a
federal court give deference to the state court's application of law to the
specific facts of the petitioner's case or should it review the state court's
determination de novo? Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens dissent.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 8, 1992
331
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-980. Colorado, et al., Petitioners v. Wendel Speer Kuhn, Jr.,
et al. The application for stay of the mandate of the Supreme Court of
Colorado, case Nos. 90SA299 and 90SA300, presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition by
this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall con-
tinue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JANUARY 10, 1992
333
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice, Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-1084. Patricia Cotlow, et al., Appellants v. James Emison, et
al. The motion of appellants to expedite consideration of the jurisdiction
statement is granted. The order entered December 5, 1991, by the
United States District Court for the District of Minnesota staying state
court proceedings is vacated.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 91-155. International Society for Krishna Consciousness, Inc.,
and Brian Rumbaugh, Petitioners v. Walter Lee; and
No. 91-339. Walter Lee, Superintendent of Port Authority Police,
Petitioner v. International Society for Krishna Consciousness, Inc., et
al. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit granted. The cases are consolidated and a total of
one hour is allotted for oral argument. Petitioners' briefs and the joint
appendix are to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing coun-
sel on or before 3 p.m., February 14, 1992. Respondents' briefs are to be
filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3
p.m., March 5, 1992. Any reply brief is to be filed with the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel in accordance with Rule 25.3. Oral argu-
ment is scheduled for the March Session beginning March 23, 1992.
No. 91-367. Carol Ankenbrandt, as Next Friend and Mother of L.R.
and S.R., Petitioner v. Jon A. Richards and Debra Kesler. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit granted limited to the following questions: (1) Is there a domes-
tic relations exception to federal jurisidction? (2) If so, does it permit a
district court to abstain from exercising diversity jurisdiction over a
tort action for damages? (3) Did the District Court in this case err in
abstaining from exercising jurisdiction under the doctrine of Younger v.
Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971)? Petitioner's brief and the joint appendix are
to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before
3 p.m., February 14, 1992. Respondents' brief is to be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., March 5,
,

334
FRIDAY, JANUARY 10, 1992
1992. Any reply brief is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon op-
posing counsel in accordance with Rule 25.3. Oral argument is sched-
uled for the March Session beginning March 23, 1992.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1992
337
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter and Justice Thomas. The Chief Justice said: "Today's or-
ders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice, filed with the
Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 91-716. In Re James Blodgett, Superintendent, Washington
State Penitentiary, et al., Petitioners. On petition for writ of manda-
mus. The motion of respondent Charles R. Campbell for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for writ of mandamus is
denied. Opinion per curiam. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in
the judgment with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 90-722. Curtis Campo, Jr., Petitioner v. Electro-Coal Transfer
Corporation, Inc.; and
No. 90-956. National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pittsburgh,
Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. Curtis Campo, Jr., et al. On petitions for
writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. The petitions for writs of certiorari are granted. The judgment
is vacated and the cases are remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of South-
west Marine, Inc. v. Gizoni, 502 U.S. (1991).
No. 90-1223. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Patricia Ramirez Rivas. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of
certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Ardestani v. Immigration and Naturalization
Service, 502 U.S. (1991).
-
No. 90-1258. Al Gomez, Warden, Deuel Vocational Institution of
California, Petiioner v. Michael Sheridan McKinney. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Estelle v.
McGuire, 502 U.S. (1991).

338
MONDAY, JANUARY 13. 1992
No. 91–206. Children of Bedford, Inc., et al., Petitioners 2. Angelo
Petromelis, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Ap-
peals of New York. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals
of New York for further consideration in light of Simon & Schuster,
Inc. v. Members of the New York State Crime Victims Board, 502 U.S.
(1991).

No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
The motion of the Special Master for Interim Fees and Expenses is
granted and the Special Master is awarded $429,457.39 to be paid in ac-
cordance with the allocation order filed by the Special Master on Octo-
ber 9, 1989. Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision
of this motion.
No. 109, Original. States of Oklahoma and Texas, Plaintiffs v. State
of New Mexico. The motion of the Special Master for compensation and
reimbursement of expenses is granted and the Special Master is
awarded a total of $14,499.45 for the period December 1, 1990, through
October 31, 1991, to be paid one-third by each party.

response to the Rule to Show Cause has been filed. Petitioner is sanc-
tioned in the amount of $1000.00 to be paid to the Clerk of the Court on
or before March 13, 1992. Justice Blackmun and Justice Souter dissent.

the University of Colorado. The motion of Public Citizen for leave to file

Brady, Secretary of the Treasury, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to

part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

ogies, Inc. and Cameron Allen. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
District of Columbia Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun would grant
certiorari.

phone Company. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Justice O'Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this petition.

No. 91-618. Daniel P. Sheehan, Petitioner v. John Hull, et al.; and

Hull, et al. The motion of Trial Lawyers for Public Justice for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of National Council
of Churches of Christ, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. Petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.

grant certiorari.

decision of these motions and this petition.

No. 91-6312. Joaquin D. Damian, Petitioner v. Federal Express

of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit before judgment is denied.

ORDER
It is ordered that Gary Kemp be, and he is hereby, appointed Deputy
Clerk of this Court, effective January 6, 1992.

TUESDAY, JANUARY 14, 1992
379
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 90-838. Shirley M. Molzof, Personal Representative of the Es-
tate of Robert E. Molzof, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Thomas.
No. 90-1126. Barbara J. Norman, et al., Petitioners v. Dorothy Reed,
et al.; and
No. 90-1435. Cook County Officers Electoral Board, et al., Petition-
ers v. Dorothy Reed, et al. On writs of certiorari to the Supreme Court
of Illinois. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part, and cases re-
manded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Scalia. Justice Thomas took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of these cases.
No. 90–408. County of Yakima, et al., Petitioners v. Confederated
Tribes and Bands of the Yakima Indian Nation; and
No. 90–577. Confederated Tribes and Bands of the Yakima Indian
Nation, Petitioner v. County of Yakima and Dale A. Gray, Yakima
County Treasurer. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed and cases remanded
to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice
Blackmun concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 90-7477. William Lewis Smith, Petitioner v. Wayne S. Barry, et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Scalia concur-
ring in the judgment.

381
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 90–741. Aletha Dewsnup, Petitioner v. Louis L. Timm, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Justice Souter joins. Justice
Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 90-954. Robert C. Rufo, Sheriff of Suffolk County, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Inmates of the Suffolk County Jail, et al.; and
No. 90-1004. Thomas C. Rapone, Commissioner of Correction of
Massachusetts, et al., Petitioners v. Inmates of the Suffolk County Jail,
et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. Judgment vacated and cases remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice White. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
Justice Blackmun joins. Justice Thomas took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of these cases.
No. 90-925. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Joseph Patrick Doherty. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. The Chief Justice announced the judg-
ment of the Court and delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to
Part I, an opinion with respect to Part II, in which Justice White, Jus-
tice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor join, and an opinion with respect to
Part III in which Justice Kennedy joins. Opinion by Justice Scalia con-
curring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part with whom Jus-
tice Stevens and Justice Souter join. Justice Thomas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 90-6113. Randall D. White, Petitioner v. Illinois. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Thomas con-

382
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 15, 1992
curring in part and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
Scalia joins.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,

The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-907. Department of Taxation and Finance of New York, et
al., Petitioners v. Milhelm Attea & Bros., Inc., aka Milhelm Attea &
Brothers, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Appellate
Division, Supreme Court of New York, Third Judicial Department. The
petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and
the case is remanded to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New
York, Third Judicial Department, for further consideration in light of
Oklahoma Tax Commission v. Citizen Band Potawatomi Indian Tribe
of Oklahoma, 498 U.S. - (1991).

CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 90-1918. Kraft General Foods, Inc., Petitioner v. Iowa Depart-
ment of Revenue and Finance. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Iowa granted.
No. 91-872. United States, Petitioner v. Anthony Salerno, et al. Pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit granted.
No. 91-744. Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania, et
al., Petitioners v. Robert P. Casey, et al., etc.; and
No. 91-902. Robert P. Casey, et al., etc., Petitioners v. Planned
Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania, et al. Petitions for writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
are granted limited to the following questions:
1. Did the Court of Appeals err in upholding the constitutionality of
the following provisions of the Pennsylvania Abortion Control Act: a. 18
Pa. Cons. Stat. Ann. Sec. 3203 (definition of medical emergency) b. 18
Pa. Cons. Stat. Ann. Sec. 3205 (informed consent) c. 18 Pa. Cons. Stat.
Ann. Sec. 3206 (parental consent) d. 18 Pa. Cons. Stat. Ann. Sections
3207, 3214 (reporting requirements)?
2. Did the Court of Appeals err in holding 18 Pa. Cons. Stat. Ann.
Sec. 3209 (spousal notice) unconstitutional? The cases are consolidated
and a total of one hour is allotted for oral argument.
No. 91–913. John R. Patterson, Trustee, Petitioner v. Joseph B.
Shumate, Jr. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United.
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted.
CERTIORARI DENIED

petitioner for leave to file petition for rehearing is denied. Justice
Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, January 27, 1992, until
Monday, February 24, 1992.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,

OPINIONS
No. 90-1342. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Jairo Jonathan Elias-Zacarias. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun and
Justice O'Connor join.
No. 112, Original. State of Wyoming, Plaintiff v. State of Oklahoma.
On Exceptions to the Report of the Special Master. Recommendations
of the Special Master adopted in part. Exceptions of Wyoming sus-
tained. Exceptions of Oklahoma rejected. Motion of Wyoming for sum-
mary judgment granted. Motion of Oklahoma for summary judgment
denied. Judgment and decree to be entered. Jurisdiction over case is
retained. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Scalia with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Thomas with whom the Chief Justice and Justice
Scalia join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1992
413
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Scalia,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1084. Patricia Cotlow, et al., Appellants v. James Emison, et
al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Min-
nesota. The order of January 10, 1992, having vacated the order from
which the appeal is taken, the appeal is dismissed as moot.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 90-1136. Arizona, Petitioner v. Patrick Henry Lengyel, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Arizona,
Division One. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals of
Arizona, Division One, for further consideration in light of White v. Illi-
nois, 502 U.S. -
(1992).
No. 91-724. Alan F. Gersman, et al., Petitioners v. Group Health
Association, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of
Columbia Circuit for further consideration in light of the Civil Rights
Act of 1991.
No. 91-5705. Darrell Prows, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Smith
v. Barry, 502 U.S. (1992).
-
