No. 119, Original. State of Connecticut, Commonwealth of Massa-
chusetts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hamp-
shire. The motion to file bill of complaint is granted. Defendant is al-
lowed 60 days in which to file an answer. The Chief Justice and Justice
Scalia would set the motion for oral argument. Justice Souter took no
part in the consideration or decision of this motion.
No. 90-1604. Dan Morales, Attorney General of Texas, Petitioner v.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. The motion of the Acting Solicitor
General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and
for divided argument is granted.
No. 90-6297. Joseph Williams, Petitioner v. United States. The par-
ties are directed to file supplemental memoranda after argument ad-
dressing the following questions: 1. When a District Court departs from
a properly constructed sentencing guideline range, and it relies on a
factor disapproved by a policy statement that guides departures, has
the District Court for that reason or otherwise made an "incorrect
application of the sentencing guidelines" within the meaning of 18
U.S.C. Sec. 3742(e)(2) and (f)(1)? 2. Are the appellate "decision and dis-
position" provisions, subsections (f)(1) and (f)(2) of 18 U.S.C. Sec. 3742,
which group the separate considerations of Sec. 3742(e), mutually ex-
clusive? 3. When a District Court bases a departure decision on an ag-
gravating or mitigating circumstance that the Court of Appeals later
determines is improper under 18 U.S.C. Sec. 3553(b), has the District
Court imposed a sentence “in violation of law" within the meaning of
Sec. 3742(e)(1) and (f)(1)? The briefs are to be filed simultaneously with
the Clerk on or before Friday, February 14, 1992.
No. 90-8370. Teofilo Medina, Jr., Petitioner v. California. The mo-
tion of Committee on Legal Problems of the Mentally Ill of the Associa-

MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1992
415
tion of the Bar of the City of New York for leave to file a brief as ami-
cus curiae is granted.
No. 91–269. Donald L. Helling, et al., Petitioners v. William McKin-
ney. The motion of respondent to retax costs is granted.
•
No. 91–594. American National Red Cross, Petitioner v. S.G. and
A.E. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.

nied. Petitioner is allowed until February 18, 1992, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.

file a brief as amici curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to

by the petition.
No. 91-810. City of Burlington, Petitioner v. Ernest Dague, Sr., et
al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Second Circuit granted limited to the following question: May a
court, in determining a reasonable attorney's fee award under Section
7002(e) of the Solid Waste Disposal Act, 42 U.S.C. Section 6972(e), or
Section 505(d) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (Clean Water
Act), 33 U.S.C. Section 1365(d), enhance the fee award above the lode-
star amount in order to reflect the fact that the attorneys had taken the

416
MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1992
case on a contingent-fee basis, thus assuming the risk of receiving no
attorney's fees at all?
No. 91–971. Two Pesos, Inc., Petitioner v. Taco Cabana Interna-
tional, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted limited to Question 1
presented by the petition.

OPINIONS
No. 90-970. Lechmere, Inc., Petitioner v. National Labor Relations
Board. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice White
with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens.
No. 90-711. Lawrence C. Presley, etc., Appellant v. Etowah County
Commission, et al.; and
No. 90-712. Ed Peter Mack and Nathaniel Gosha, III, etc., Appel-
lants v. Russell County Commission, et al. Appeals from the United
States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama. Judgment af-
firmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice White and Justice Blackmun join.

431
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-551. James Baker, III, Secretary of State, et al., Applicants
v. Haitian Refugee Center, Inc., et al. The application of the Solicitor
General for stay, presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to
the Court, is granted. It is ordered that the order of the United States.
District Court for the Southern District of Florida, case No. 91-2635-
CIV-Atkins, filed December 20, 1991, is stayed pending disposition of
the appeal by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir-
cuit. Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens and Justice Thomas would deny
the application.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-1292. Haitian Refugee Center, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
James Baker, III, Secretary of State, et al. The application for stay of
mandate of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
presented to Justice Kennedy, has been referred to the Court by him.
The motion of petitioners for temporary waiver of Rule 33 is granted.
The Solicitor General is directed to file a response to the application for
stay and the petition for a writ of certiorari on or before 3 p.m. Friday,
February 14, 1992. Justice Blackmun would grant the application for
stay at this time.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1992
439
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER
Pursuant to the authority conferred by the Constitution and Statutes
of the United States, and more particularly by 28 U. S. C. Section 42
(1982), the Court hereby assigns and allots the Honorable Clarence
Thomas as a Circuit Justice for the United States Court of Appeals for
the District of Columbia Circuit for the day of February 19, 1992.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1992
441
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 91-7146. Leonel Torres Herrera, Petitioner v. Texas. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.
Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would grant the application for
stay of execution and the petition for a writ of certiorari.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-604. Leonel Torres Herrera, Applicant v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Black-
mun, Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, and Justice Souter would
grant the application for stay of execution.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-604. Leonel Torres Herrera, Applicant v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The motion to treat the application for a stay of execution as a petition
for a writ of certiorari is denied. Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens,
Justice O'Connor, and Justice Souter would grant the motion and would
grant the petition for a writ of certiorari.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 91-7328. Leonel Torres Herrera, Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for a
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit are granted. The order of this date denying the application for
stay of execution of sentence of death is to remain in effect.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1992
445
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 90-1246. Immigration and Naturalization Service, Petitioner v.
Jose Roberto Canas-Segovia, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Immigration and Naturalization
Service v. Elias-Zacarias, 502 U. S. (1992).
-
No. 91-974. Robert Lee Holland, Petitioner v. First Virginia Banks,
Inc. and Donald Brennan. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit
for further consideration in light of the Civil Rights Act of 1991.
No. 91-5447. Phillip Elliott Jones, Petitioner v. Tekla Miller. On pe-
tition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Smith
v. Barry, 502 U. S. (1992).
No.
-

Jessie E. Davis, Petitioner v. Clerk of the Supreme Court
of the United States, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a peti-
tion for a writ of certiorari is denied.

leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indigency ex-
ecuted by the petitioner is granted.

No. D-1081. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael J. Stella. It is
ordered that Michael J. Stella, of Harrison, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1082. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lawrence Wayne
Solodky. It is ordered that Lawrence Wayne Solodky, of Longwood,
Florida, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1083. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harold Jack Gattsek. It
is ordered that Harold Jack Gattsek, of Annandale, Virginia, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1084. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jeffrey Lee Greenspan.
It is ordered that Jeffrey Lee Greenspan, of Rockville, Maryland, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for approval of fees and expenses is
granted and the River Master is awarded $7,644.00 for the period Octo-
ber 1 - December 31, 1991, to be paid equally by the parties.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New
York. The Report of the Special Master is received and ordered filed.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1992
447
Exceptions to the Report, with supporting briefs, may be filed by the
parties within 45 days. Replies, if any, may be filed within 30 days.
No. 90-1488. Sue Suter, et al., Petitioners v. Artist M., et al. The
motion of respondents for leave to file a supplemental brief after argu-
ment is granted. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a supplemen-
tal brief after argument is granted.
No. 90-1604. Dan Morales, Attorney General of Texas, Petitioner v.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. The motion of Public Citizen, et al. for
leave to participate in oral argument as amici curiae, for divided argu-
ment and for additional time for oral argument is denied.

No. 91–501. Jose E. Aponte, Mayor of the Municipality of Carolina,

lants v. Montana, et al. The motion of Attorney General of Washington

tion of Attorney General of Massachusetts for leave to participate in
oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided argument and for addi-
tional time for oral argument is denied.

448
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1992
No. 91–1193. New Berlin Grading Co., Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
National Labor Relations Board. The application for stay addressed to
the Chief Justice and referred to the Court is denied.
No. 91-1270. Ann Richards, Governor of Texas, et al., Appellants v.
Louis Terrazas, et al. The motion of appellants to expedite consider-
ation of the statement as to jurisdiction is denied.
No. 91-5771. Harold Ray Wade, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers for leave
to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided argument
and for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 91-6734. Maurice J. Neshewat, Petitioner v. David D. Hag-
strom, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is denied. Petitioner is allowed until March 16, 1992, within which
to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens,
dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc.,
464 U. S. 928 (1983), I would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari
without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
No. 91-6854. Robert G. Ingalls, Petitioner v. Roosevelt County,
New Mexico, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until March 16, 1992,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v.
Herald Co., Inc., 464 U. S. 928 (1983), I would deny the petition for a
writ of certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed
in forma pauperis.

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1992
485
Opinion by Justice Thomas respecting the denial of certiorari. Opinion
by Justice Blackmun dissenting from the denial of certiorari.

MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 91-6444. In Re Robert Carroll, Petitioner;
No. 91-6578. In Re Milton S. Hall and Melvin L. Washington,
Petitioners;
No. 91-6696. In Re Lorenzo Arteaga, Petitioner; and
No. 91-6714. In Re Grant Anderson, Petitioner. The petitions for
writs of mandamus are denied.
PROHIBITION DENIED
No. 91-6687. In Re Kevin Burke, Petitioner; and
No. 91-6695. In Re Lorenzo Arteaga, Petitioner. The petitions for
writs of prohibition are denied.

opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.

for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring
in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and con-
curring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas with
whom Justice Scalia joins.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MARCH 2, 1992
507
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice. Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-6255. Floy Siggers, et al., Appellants v. Tunica County
Board of Supervisors, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Mississippi. The motion of appellees
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Mississippi with instructions to dismiss the ap-
peal as moot. United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U.S. 36 (1950).
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1116. Kenneth Hicks, Petitioner v. Brown Group, Inc., dba
Brown Shoe Company, Inc. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
for further consideration in light of the Civil Rights Act of 1991.
No. 91-6586. Edward Dean, Petitioner v. Veterans Administration.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The
judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit to consider whether Rule 15(c) of
the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, as amended, applies to this case.

ordered that Donald J. Kenney, of Safford, Arizona, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

ordered that Ralph A. Nuzzo, of Fairfield, New Jersey, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

titioner is allowed until March 23, 1992, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38 and to submit a petition in com-
pliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 91-6781. Richard P. Kattula, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until March 23, 1992, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

MONDAY, MARCH 9, 1992
531
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and
Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 90–7699. Larry Minniefield, Petitioner v. Sylvester Perkins. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Hud-
son v. McMillian, 503 U.S. (1992).
-
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Sammy Vanwoudenberg, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. The mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis without an affidavit of indi-
gency executed by the petitioner is granted.
No. D-1060. In the Matter of Disbarment of Todd Eric Blumenfeld.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1061. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth L. Waldron.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1064. In the Matter of Disbarment of Norman F. Solomon.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1067. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerome Stanley Cardin.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1091. In the Matter of Disbarment of Granville H. Crabtree,
Jr. It is ordered that Granville H. Crabtree, Jr., of Sarasota, Florida,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1092. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stephen John Devine.
It is ordered that Stephen John Devine, of Norristown, Pennsylvania,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule

532
MONDAY, MARCH 9, 1992
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1093. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alan E. Robbins. It is
ordered that Alan E. Robbins, of Van Nuys, California, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

and Colorado. The motion of National Audubon Society for leave to file
a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Platt River Whoop-
ing Crane Critical Habitat Maintenance Trust for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted.
No. 90-747. United States Department of State, Petitioner v. Mi-
chael D. Ray, et al. The motion of respondents to retax costs is denied.
Justice Blackmun would grant this motion.

tion Agency, Petitioner v. National Solid Wastes Management Associa-
tion. The motion of the Solicitor General to permit William K. Kelly,
Esquire, to present oral argument pro hac vice is granted.

Company, et al. The motion of Petroleum Helicopters, Inc., et al. for

is granted.

torney General of Virginia, Petitioners v. Frank Robert West, Jr. The
motion of the Attorney General of North Dakota to withdraw as amicus
curiae is granted.

States; and

OPINIONS
No. 90-1791. Connecticut National Bank, Petitioner v. Thomas M.
Germain, Trustee for the Estate of O'Sullivan's Fuel Oil Co., Inc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Thomas. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in
the judgment. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in the judgment
with whom Justice White and Justice Blackmun join.
No. 90-6616. James R. Stringer, Petitioner v. Lee Roy Black, Com-
missioner, Mississippi Department of Corrections, et al. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-

MONDAY, MARCH 9, 1992
545
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter with whom
Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas join.
No. 90-6297. Joseph Williams, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment vacated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for
further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with
whom Justice Kennedy joins.
No. 90-1390. General Motors Corporation, et al., Petitioners v.
Evert Romein, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Michigan. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice O'Connor.
No. 90-6704. David Dawson, Petitioner v. Delaware. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Delaware. Judgment vacated and case
remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Con-
curring opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Thomas.
No. 91-122. PFZ Properties, Inc., Petitioner v. Rene Alberto Rodri-
guez, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the First Circuit. The writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvi-
dently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by the Chief Justice.

TUESDAY, MARCH 10, 1992
549
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,

CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 91-7568. Robyn Leroy Parks, Petitioner v. Dan Reynolds, War-
den, et al. The application for stay of execution of sentence of death
presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is denied.
The petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit is denied.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, MARCH 11, 1992
551
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Conner, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-615. Allied-Signal, Inc., as Successor-in-Interest to The Ben-
dix Corporation, Petitioner v. Director, Division of Taxation. This case
is restored to the calendar for reargument during the April Session.
The parties are requested to simultaneously file with the Clerk of the
Court and serve upon the parties, on or before 3:00 p.m., Friday, April
10, 1992, supplemental briefs addressing the following questions:
1. Should the Court overrule Asarco v. Idaho State Tax Commis-
sion, 458 U.S. 307 (1982), and F.W. Woolworth Co. v. Taxation & Rev-
enue Department, 458 U.S. 354 (1982)?
2. If Asarco and Woolworth were overruled, should the decision.
apply retroactively?
3. If Asarco and Woolworth were overruled, what constitutional
principles should govern state taxation of corporations doing business
in several states?
Replies thereto, if any, are to be filed with the Clerk and served upon
the parties on or before noon, Friday, April 17, 1992. The views of
amici curiae are invited.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-1420. Joan Growe, Secretary of State of Minnesota, et al.,
Appellants v. James Emison, et al. The motion to expedite consider-
ation of the jurisdictional statement is granted. Appellees' response to
the jurisdictional statement is to be filed with the Clerk of the Court
and served upon counsel for the appellants on or before 1:00 p.m., Mon-
day, March 23, 1992.

PROBABLE JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 91–1502. Barbara Franklin, Secretary of Commerce, et al., Ap-
pellants v. Massachusetts, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Massachusetts. The motion to expedite consid-
eration of the statement as to jurisdiction is granted. In this case proba-
ble jurisdiction is noted. The motion to permit filings initially in type-
written form is granted. The joint appendix is to be filed by
Wednesday, March 25, 1992. If the State of Washington should wish to
file any further papers on the application for stay, it must do so by
Wednesday, March 25, 1992. Briefs on the merits are to be filed by the
parties with the Clerk of this Court and served upon the parties on or
before 3:00 p.m., Monday, April 13, 1992. Replies thereto, if any, are to
be filed with the Clerk and served upon the parties on or before 3:00
p.m., Monday, April 20, 1992. The case is set for oral argument on
Tuesday, April 21, 1992.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

APPEALS SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 90–1977. Johnny Dupree, et al., Appellants v. Mike Moore, At-
torney General of Mississippi, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Mississippi. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States District Court for
the Southern District of Mississippi for further consideration in light of
Clark v. Roemer, 500 U.S. — (1991).
-
No. 91-1210. Bill Clinton, Governor of Arkansas, et al., Petitioners
v. M.C. Jeffers, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Eastern District of Arkansas. The judgment is vacated and the case
is remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern Dis-
trict of Arkansas with instructions to enter a fresh judgment from
which an appeal may be taken to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 90-1164. Willie Albert Smith, Petitioner v. Lee Roy Black,
Commissioner, Mississippi Department of Corrections, et al. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Stringer v. Black, 503 U.S. (1992).
No. 91-432. Randolph Moore, Petitioner v. Nevada. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nevada. The petition for writ
of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Nevada for further consideration in
light of Dawson v. Delaware, 503 U.S. (1992).
-
No. 91-701. Illinois, Petitioner v. John P. Kelk. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District. The pe-

562
MONDAY, MARCH 23, 1992
tition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District, for
further consideration in light of Florida v. Jimeno, 500 U.S.
(1991). Justice Stevens dissents.
No. 91-885. Steven L. Easley, Petitioner v. Southern Shipbuilding
Corporation. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari
is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Southwest Marine, Inc. v. Gizoni, 502 U.S.
(1991).
-
No. 91-5293. Dale Edward Flanagan, Petitioner v. Nevada. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Nevada. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Nevada for further consideration in
light of Dawson v. Delaware, 503 U.S. - (1992).
No. 91-5787. Darrell Prows, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Mc-
Carthy v. Madigan, 503 U.S. (1992).

No. 91-6700. Kenneth Michael Kochekian, Petitioner v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of

proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the

(1992).

discharged.

certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit
denied. Justice White would grant certiorari.
No. 91-1240. Daniel Engelke, Petitioner v. Gregory A. Scher. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit denied.
No. 91-1280. Walter Zant, Warden, Petitioner v. Jimmy Lee Hor-
ton. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit denied.
No. 91-7002. Clark Albert Bailey, Petitioner v. Arthur E. Noot,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of

MONDAY, MARCH 23, 1992
585
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice
White with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 91-7239. Charles Merrill Mount, Petitioner v. United States.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun took no part in the consider-
ation or decision of this petition.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 91-7451. In Re Tyrone Hiawatha Lee, Petitioner. The petition
for a writ of habeas corpus is denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 91-7084. In Re Rachel C. Martin, Petitioner;
No. 91-7085. In Re Robert S. Meade, Petitioner;
No. 91-7256. In Re Charles Cox, Petitioner; and
No. 91-7428. In Re Orville Johns, Petitioner. The petitions for
writs of mandamus are denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 91–899. Lorin G. Sloan, Petitioner v. United States;
No. 91-5477. Lonnie James Brown, Petitioner v. United States;

ing Warden, et al.; and
No. 91-6649. Herbert Greene, Petitioner v. Teledyne Electronics.
The petitions for rehearing are denied.
No. 91-5694. John Ferguson, Petitioner v. Giant Foods, Inc. The
petition for rehearing is denied. Justice Thomas took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MARCH 24, 1992
595
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 90–1745. United States, Petitioner v. Richard Wilson. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
Justice White joins.
No. 90-727. Robert G. Holmes, Jr., Petitioner v. Securities Investor
Protection Corporation, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor concurring in part and concurring in the judgment
with whom Justice White and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Justice
Scalia concurring in the judgment.
No. 90-1577. United States, Petitioner v. R.L.C. On writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Justice Souter announced the judgment of the Court
and delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II-A, and
III, and an opinion with respect to Parts II-B and II-C, in which the
Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice Stevens join. Opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia concurring in part and concurring in the judgment with
whom Justice Kennedy and Justice Thomas join. Opinion by Justice
Thomas concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 90-1802. Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Robert T. Darden. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, MARCH 27, 1992
599
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-700. Billy Joe Camp, Secretary of State of Alabama, Applicant
v. Paul Charles Wesch, et al. The application for stay presented to Jus-
tice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied. The motion to
expedite consideration of the jurisdictional statement is denied. The
motion to permit filings initially in typewritten form is granted.
No. 91-1502. Barbara Franklin, Secretary of Commerce, et al., Ap-
pellants v. Massachusetts, et al. The application for stay presented to
Justice Souter and by him referred to the Court is granted and it is or-
dered that the judgment of the United States District Court for the
District of Massachusetts, case No. Civ. 91–11234-WD, is stayed pend-
ing disposition of the appeal in this Court. In the event the judgment is
affirmed, this order is to terminate automatically. If the judgment is
vacated or reversed, this stay is to remain in effect pending the sending
down of the judgment of this Court.

MONDAY, MARCH 30, 1992
601
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
No. -
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Luis Cuevas, Applicant v. United States. The motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is
denied.

No. Edward Halas, Applicant v. Donald J. Quigg. The motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time,
is denied.

tion for release addressed to Justice White and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. A-689. Lester M. Ayars, et ux., Applicants v. New Jersey. The
application for bail addressed to Justice White and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. D-1065. In the Matter of Eric Steven Solowitch. Eric Steven
Solowitch, of University Heights, Ohio, having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar of this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on January 13, 1992,
is hereby discharged.

Disbarment order entered.

602
MONDAY, MARCH 30, 1992
No. D-1099. In the Matter of Disbarment of Henry Clay Hart, Jr. It
is ordered that Henry Clay Hart, Jr., of Morgantown, West Virginia,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1100. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Eaton Cunning-
ham. It is ordered that Michael Eaton Cunningham, of Brick, New Jer-
sey, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1101. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mark Temple Watson. It
is ordered that Mark Temple Watson, of Elizabeth, Kentucky, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1102. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kurt R. Conner. It is
ordered that Kurt R. Conner, of North Wilkesboro, North Carolina, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1103. In the Matter of Disbarment of Newton Alfred Winn. It
is ordered that Newton Alfred Winn, of St. Petersburg, Florida, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1104. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gary L. Blank. It is or-
dered that Gary L. Blank, of Chicago, Illinois, be suspended from the
practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1105. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter G. Mekas. It is
ordered that Peter G. Mekas, of Reed City, Michigan, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for di-
vided argument is granted.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

OPINIONS
No. 89–1290. Robert R. Freeman, et al., Petitioners v. Willie Eu-
gene Pitts, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring
opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice Souter. Opin-
ion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment with whom Justice
Stevens and Justice O'Connor join. Justice Thomas took no part in the
consideration or decision of this case.
No. 91-860. United States Department of Commerce, et al., Appel-
lants v. Montana, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Montana. Judgment reversed and case remaned to
the District Court for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens.

SATURDAY, APRIL 4, 1992
623
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-735. Samuel A. Lewis, Director of Corrections of Arizona, et
al., Applicants v. Donald Eugene Harding. The application to vacate
the stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice O'Con-
nor and by her referred to the Court is granted and it is ordered that
the order staying the execution entered by the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on April 2, 1992, is vacated. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the application.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1992
625
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN Pending CasE
No. A-737. Donald Eugene Harding, Applicant v. Samuel A. Lewis,
Director of Corrections of Arizona, et al. The application to stay the
execution of sentence of death presented to Justice O'Connor and by
her referred to the Court is denied.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 91-6751. Joe Mario Trevino, Petitioner v. Texas. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The pe-
tition for writ of certiorari is granted. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Criminal Appeals for further proceedings not
inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-1062. In the Matter of Disbarment of Peter P. Tavolacci. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1070. In the Matter of Disbarment of Vincent Mosser Dunn.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1079. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert P. McNamee.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1106. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard Horowitz. It is
ordered that Howard Horowitz, of Coral Gables, Florida, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1107. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert B. Chatz. It is
ordered that Robert B. Chatz, of Northbrook, Illinois, be suspended

626
MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1992
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1108. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Franklin Rosch. It
is ordered that John Franklin Rosch, of Glen Ellyn, Illinois, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 90-114. Consolidation Coal Company, Petitioner v. Director, Of-
fice of Workers' Compensation Programs, United States Department of
Labor, et al. The motion of respondent Albert C. Dayton for award of
attorney fees is denied without prejudice to refiling in the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Justice Kennedy and
Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 91-615. Allied-Signal, Inc., as Successor-in-Interest to The
Bendix Corporation, Petitioner v. Director, Division of Taxation. The
motion of the Attorney General of Commonwealth of Virginia for leave
to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae, for divided argument
and for additional time for oral argument is denied.
No. 91-719. Al C. Parke, Warden, Petitioner v. Ricky Harold
Raley. The motion of petitioner to be excused from printing certain por-
tions of the record in the joint appendix is denied.
No. 91-810. City of Burlington, Petitioner v. Ernest Dague, Sr., et
al. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted. The
motion of respondents for divided argument to permit American Bar
Association to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae is denied.
No. 91-913. John R. Patterson, Trustee, Petitioner v. Joseph B.
Shumate, Jr. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to partici-
pate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is
granted.
No. 91–998. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Nader
E. Soliman. The motion of the Solicitor General to dispense with print-
ing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 91-1514. Anne Arundel County Republican Central Committee,
et al., Appellants v. The State Administrative Board of Election Laws,
et al. The motion of appellants to expedite consideration of the appeal is
denied.

MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1992
627
No. 91-1571. Massachusetts, et al., Appellants v. Barbara Franklin,
Secretary of Commerce, et al. The motion of appellants to expedite con-
sideration of the appeal is denied. The motion of appellants to permit
filings initially in typewritten form is granted.
No. 91-1566. Republican Party of Oregon, et al., Petitioners v. Phil
Keisling, Secretary of State of Oregon. The motion of petitioners to ex-
pedite consideration of the petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. 91-7344. Harry L. Reynolds, Petitioner v. Local 24, United
Steel Workers of America, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until April
27, 1992, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a)
and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court.

OPINION
No. 90-1124. Keith Jacobson, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom
the Chief Justice and Justice Kennedy join, and with whom Justice
Scalia joins except as to Part II.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1992
645
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"It gives me great pleasure today to recognize that this is the thirti-
eth anniversary of Justice White's appointment to this Court. He was
appointed on April 16, 1962 and has served with distinction ever since.
It has been a pleasure to have you as a colleague Justice White. We all
feel that way."
Justice White said:
"You may hold the applause."
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 89-1681. Board of Education of Topeka, Shawnee County, Kan-
sas, Petitioner v. Oliver Brown, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The peti-
tion for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the
case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Freeman v. Pitts, 503 U.S.
(1992), and Board of Education of Oklahoma City Public Schools,
Independent School District No. 80, Oklahoma County, Oklahoma v.
Dowell, 498 U.S. - (1991).
No. 90-1527. United States, Petitioner v. Claudio Calderone and
Domenico Catalano, aka Micu. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
for further consideraton in light of United States v. Felix, 503 U.S.
(1992).
No. 91-31. United States, Petitioner v. Giuseppe Gambino. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of

646
MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1992
Appeals for the Second Circuit for further consideration in light of
United States v. Felix, 503 U.S. — (1992).
No. 91-900. Paul Caspari and William Webster, Petitioners v. Terry
D. McIntyre, Director, Missouri Division of Classification and Treat-
ment. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further con-
sideration in light of United States v. Felix, 503 U.S. — (1992).
No. 91-1340. William H. Dennler, et al., Petitioners v. Robert Trip-
pet, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Section 27 of the Securities and Exchange Act of
1934. Justice Thomas took no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. - Paul Carroll, et al., Petitioners v. United States. The mo-
tion to direct the Clerk to file a petition that does not conform with the
Rules of this Court is denied.
No. . Patricia John, Petitioner v. North Community Bank, et al.
The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari,
out-of-time, is denied.
No.
William B. Schmidt, Petitioner v. Dee Ann Ransone
Schmidt. The motion to dispense with printing the petition for a writ of
certiorari is denied.
No. A-702. John F. Freas, Applicant v. New Jersey. The application
for stay addressed to Justice White and referred to the Court is denied.
No. A-718. Maria Luisa Constall Gaydos, Applicant v. Timothy J.
Gaydos, et al. The application for stay addressed to the Chief Justice.
and referred to the Court is denied.
No. D-1078. In the Matter of Disbarment of Melville Herman Beh-
rendt, Jr. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1081. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael J. Stella. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1082. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lawrence Wayne Sol-
odky. Disbarment order entered.

MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1992
647
No. D-1083. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harold Jack Gattsek.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1109. In the Matter of Disbarment of Daniel V. Presnick. It
is ordered that Daniel V. Presnick, of Orange, Connecticut, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1110. In the Matter of Disbarment of Phil L. Hansen. It is
ordered that Phil L. Hansen, of Salt Lake City, Utah, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1111. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harvey Tessler. It is
ordered that Harvey Tessler, of St. Louis, Missouri, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1112. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ivan Vance White, Jr..
It is ordered that Ivan Vance White, Jr., of Wilmington, North Caro-
lina, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1113. In the Matter of Disbarment of Hilton Davis. It is or-
dered that Hilton Davis, of Newark, New Jersey, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1114. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gladys E. Harrison. It
is ordered that Gladys E. Harrison, of Cleveland, Ohio, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring her to show cause why she should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1115. In the Matter of Disbarment of John B. D'Albora. It is
ordered that John B. D'Albora, of Brooklyn, New York, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The sixth motion of the Special Master for compensation
and reimbursement of expenses is granted and the Special Master is

648
MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1992
awarded a total of $233,144.11. Assessment of this award is deferred
pending receipt of further responses by Colorado and the amici curiae
to the special assessment proposed by the Special Master, to be filed on
or before Monday, May 4, 1992, and further order of the Court.
No. 91-744. Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania, et
al., Petitioners v. Robert P. Casey, et al., etc.; and
No. 91-902. Robert P. Casey, et al., etc., Petitioners v. Planned Par-
enthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania, et al. The motion of James J.
Crook for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of
America 21, Family Values for the Twenty-First Century for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is denied. The motion of Arlen Specter to
join amici curiae brief of Don Edwards, et al. is granted.
No. 91-913. John R. Patterson, Trustee, Petitioner v. Joseph B.
Shumate, Jr. The motion of Hallmark Cards, Inc. for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Wal-Mart Stores, et al. for
leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of Eldon S.
Reed for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of
Ronald J. Wyles, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is
granted. The motion of ERISA Industry Committee, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae is granted. The motion of Lincoln National
Corporation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The
motion of American Society of Pension Actuaries for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Chamber of Commerce of
the United States of America for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of American College of Trust and Estate Counsel
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
No. 91-1208. Drilake Farms, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Julio Sur-
rillo, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case
expressing the views of the United States.
No. 91-1353. Thomas F. Conroy, Petitioner v. Walter Aniskoff, Jr.,
et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in this case express-
ing the views of the United States.
No. 91-1502. Barbara Franklin, Secretary of Commerce, et al., ap-
pellants v. Massachusetts, et al. The motion of Attorney General of
Washington for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae,
for divided argument and for additional time for oral argument is
denied.

v. Barney Quilter, Speaker Pro Tempore of Ohio House of Represent-
atives, et al. The application to stay an order of the United States Dis-

MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1992
649
trict Court for the Northern District of Ohio, filed March 17, 1992, and
supplemented April 6, 1992, presented to Justice Stevens and by him
referred to the Court is granted and it is ordered that the orders of the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, case
No. 5:91 CV 2219, entered March 10, 1992, and March 31, 1992, are

No. 91-6854. Robert G. Ingalls, Petitioner v. Roosevelt County,
New Mexico, et al. The motion of petitioner for reconsideration of order
denying leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Justice Black-
mun and Justice Stevens would grant this motion.
No. 91-7325. John Robert Demos, Jr., Petitioner v. Supreme Court
of Washington, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until
May 11, 1992, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule
38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules
of this Court. Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari.
No. 91-7376. Jessie D. McDonald, Petitioner v. Yellow Cab Metro,
Inc., et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until May 11, 1992,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.
No. 91-7377. Johannes G. Mooyman, Petitioner v. Workmen's Com-
pensation Appeal Board, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until May 11,
1992, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and
to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court.
No. 91-7504. Priya K. Das, Petitioner v. A. W. Chesterton Com-
pany. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. Petitioner is allowed until May 11, 1992, within which to pay
the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in
compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Stevens, dis-
senting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co., Inc., 464
U.S. 928 (1983), I would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari with-
out reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma pauperis.

No. 91–1136. Erwin Rautenberg, et al., Petitioners v. United States
District Court for the Central District of California (United States, et
al., Real Parties in Interest). The motion of petitioners for leave to file
an unredacted petition for a writ of certiorari under seal is granted. The
motion of the Solicitor General for leave to file a brief in opposition ini-
tially under seal and to lift seal on brief in opposition and on the prior
filing is granted. The motion of petitioners for leave to file a reply brief
and addendum to reply brief under seal is granted and the seal is lifted.
The motion of petitioners to file motion to take judicial notice under seal
is granted. The seal is lifted and the motion to take judicial notice is
granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit is denied.

motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit denied.

respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas denied.

ORDER
It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for any special as-
signments, be suspended for the Term upon the conclusion of the argu-
ments in the cases listed for hearing this week.
RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from Monday, April 27, 1992, until Mon-
day, May 4, 1992.

TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 1992
679
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN Pending CasE
No. A-766. Daniel Vasquez, Warden, Applicant v. Robert Alton
Harris. The application to vacate the stay of execution of sentence of
death presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is
granted, and it is ordered that the order staying the execution entered
by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in
No. 92-55426 on April 20, 1992, is vacated.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. A-767. James Gomez and Daniel Vasquez, Applicants v. United
States District Court for the Northern District of California, et al. The
application to vacate the stay of execution of death is granted, and it is
ordered that the orders staying the execution of Robert Alton Harris.
entered by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in
No. 92-70237 on April 20, 1992 are vacated. Opinion per curiam. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-768. Daniel Vasquez, Warden, Applicant v. Robert Alton
Harris. The application to vacate the stay of execution of sentence of
death presented to Justice O'Connor and by her referred to the Court is
granted, and it is ordered that the order staying the execution entered
by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on April
21, 1992, is vacated. No further stays of Robert Alton Harris' execution
shall be entered by the federal courts except upon order of this Court.
Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the application.
OPINIONS
No. 91-571. Robert J. Taylor, Trustee, Petitioner v. Freeland &
Kronz, Wendell G. Freeland and Richard F. Kronz. On writ of certio-

680
TUESDAY, APRIL 21, 1992
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judg-
ment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens.
No. 90-1341. United States Department of Energy, Petitioner v.
Ohio, et al.; and
No. 90-1517. Ohio, et al., Petitioners v. United States Department of
Energy. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and cases remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice
White concurring in part and dissenting in part with whom Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens join.
No. 91–611. Keyton E. Barker and Pauline Barker, et al., Petitioners
v. Kansas, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kansas.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
Justice Thomas joins.
No. 118, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of
Alaska. On motions for preliminary judgment. The motion of the
United States for summary judgment is granted. The motion of Alaska
for summary judgment is denied. Opinion by Justice White.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-775. Gene McNary, Commissioner, Immigration and Natural-
ization Service, et al., Applicants v. Haitian Centers Council, Inc., et
al. The application for a stay of preliminary injunction presented to
Justice Thomas and by him referred to the Court is granted, and it is
ordered that the preliminary injunction entered on April 6, 1992, and
clarified on April 15, 1992, by the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of New York, case No. 92 CV 1258, is stayed pending
disposition of the appeal by the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the
application. Dissenting statement by Justice O'Connor, with whom Jus-
tice Souter joins.

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1992

for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, APRIL 27, 1992
685
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice White, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice
O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and Justice
Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1075. George Lewis Bailes, Jr., Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted.
The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit with instructions to remand
the case to the United States District Court for the Northern District of
Alabama with instructions to vacate with prejudice that aspect of the
district court's award that represents the “doubling" of damages as sug-
gested by the Solicitor General in his brief for the United States filed
April 1, 1992, and for further appropriate proceedings.
No.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
Edward Halas, Petitioner v. Donald J. Quigg. The motion
of petitioner for reconsideration of order denying motion to direct the
Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.
No. D-1087. In the Matter of Disbarment of H. Lawrence Fox. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1088. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arnold I. Kramer. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1116. In the Matter of Disbarment of Norris Muldrow. It is
ordered that Norris Muldrow, of Cincinnati, Ohio, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
119, Original. State of Connecticut, Commonwealth of Massachu-
setts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hampshire.
It is ordered that the Honorable Vincent L. McKusick, retired Chief
Justice, Supreme Judicial Court of Maine, be appointed Special Master
in this case with authority to fix the time and conditions for the filing of

686
MONDAY, APRIL 27, 1992
additional pleadings and to direct subsequent proceedings, and with au-
thority to summon witnesses, issue subpoenas, and take such evidence
as may be introduced and such as he may deem it necessary to call for.
The Master is directed to submit such reports as he may deem appro-
priate. The compensation of the Special Master, the allowances to him,
the compensation paid to his legal, technical, stenographic, and clerical
assistants, the cost of printing his report, and all other proper ex-
penses, including travel expenses, shall be charged against and be
borne by the parties in such proportion as the Court may hereafter di-
rect. Justice Souter took no part in the consideration or decision of this
order.
No. 91-321. Itel Containers International Corporation, Petitioner v.
Joe Huddleston, Commissioner of Revenue of Tennessee. The motion of
petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 91-1010. Puerto Rico Aqueduct and Sewer Authority, Peti-
tioner v. Metcalf & Eddy, Inc. The motion of petitioner to dispense with
printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 91-615. Allied-Signal, Inc., as successor-in-interest to The Ben-
dix Corporation, Petitioner v. Director, Division of Taxation. The mo-
tion of respondent to strike the amici curiae brief of General Motors
Corporation, et al. is denied. The motion of respondent to strike the
amicus curiae brief of Georgia Coalition of Military Federal Retirees,
Inc. is granted.
No. 91-990. Dale Farrar and Pat Smith, Co-Administrators of Es-
tate of Joseph D. Farrar, deceased, Petitioners v. William P. Hobby,
Jr. The motion of American Bar Association for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted.
No. 91-1188. James Rowland, Former Director, California Depart-
ment of Corrections, et al., Petitioners v. California Men's Colony, Unit
II Men's Adv. Council. Further consideration of the motion of respond-
ent for leave to proceed further herein in forma pauperis is deferred to
the hearing of the case on the merits. The Clerk is directed to print re-
spondent's brief on the merits.
No. 91-1326. The District of Columbia and Sharon Pratt Kelly,
Mayor, Petitioners v. The Greater Washington Board of Trade. The
motion of petitioners to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 91-1340. William H. Dennler, et al., Petitioners v. Robert Trip-
pet, et al. The order entered April 20, 1992, is amended to read as fol-
lows: The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is

MONDAY, APRIL 27, 1992
687
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of Section 27A of
the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934. Justice Thomas took no part
in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 91-1423. Railroad Commission of Texas, et al., Petitioners v.
Missouri Pacific Railroad, et al. The Solicitor General is invited to file a
brief in this case expressing the views of the United States.
No. 91-7403. John Robert Demos, Jr., Petitioner v. Supreme Court
of Washington. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until May 18,
1992, within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and
to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the petition
for a writ of certiorari.
No. 91-7540. Robert Calhoun, Jr., Petitioner v. United States, et al.
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is de-
nied. Petitioner is allowed until May 18, 1992, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
No. 91-7550. Ruben Rodriguez Lopez, Petitioner v. California. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until May 18, 1992, within which to pay the doc-
keting fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance
with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

FRIDAY, MAY 1, 1992
701
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-8111. Edward D. Kennedy, Petitioner v. Harry K. Single-
tary, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Ken-
nedy and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the
disposition by this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted,
this stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this
Court.

MONDAY, MAY 4, 1992
705
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice White, Justice Blackmun, Justice O'Connor, Justice
Scalia, Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 90–1972. United States, Petitioner v. John H. Williams, Jr. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with
whom Justice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor join and with whom Jus-
tice Thomas joins as to parts II and III.
No. 90-1846. George F. Denton, Director of Corrections of Califor-
nia, et al., Petitioners v. Mike Hernandez. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Stevens with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 90-1859. J. C. Keeney, Superintendent, Oregon State Peniten-
tiary, Petitioner v. Jose Tamayo-Reyes. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the United States District Court for the
District of Oregon for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice O'Connor with whom Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens and Jus-
tice Kennedy join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy.

707
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 91-7832. Justin Lee May, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Direc-
tor, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit is denied.
CERTIORARI DENIED

tor, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit is denied.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 11, 1992
711
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice. Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-838. Nollie Lee Martin, Applicant v. Harry K. Singletary,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The application for stay
of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy and by
him referred to the Court is denied.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 91-8190. Nollie Lee Martin, Petitioner v. Harry K. Singletary,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Kennedy
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida is denied.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, MAY 13, 1992
713
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-829. David Gantt, etc., et al., Applicants v. Dean Skelos, etc.,
et al. The application to stay an order of the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of New York presented to Justice
Thomas and by him referred to the Court is granted and it is ordered
that the portion of the order of the United States District Court for the
Eastern District of New York, case Nos. CV-92-1521 (SJ) and CV-92-
1776 (SJ), entered May 5, 1992, enjoining further proceedings in Reid
v. Marino, Index No. 9567/92, now pending in the Supreme Court of
New York, County of Kings, is stayed pending the timely filing and dis-
position of an appeal in this Court. Further consideration of the motion
to expedite is deferred to the timely filing of a statement as to jurisdic-
tion in the above-entitled appeal.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, MAY 18, 1992
715
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1553. Billy Joe Camp, Secretary of State of Alabama, Appel-
lant v. Paul Charles Wesch, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Alabama. The judgment is
affirmed.
CERTIORARI—SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-169. Manuel Lujan, Jr., Secretary of the Interior, et al., Pe-
titioners v. Sierra Club, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
for further consideration in light of United States Department of En-
ergy v. Ohio, 503 U.S. (1992).
No. 91-1475. Florida, Petitioner v. Roosevelt Walker. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fifth
District. The motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma paupe-
ris is granted. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the District Court of Ap-
peal of Florida, Fifth District, for further consideration in light of
McNeil v. Wisconsin, 501 U.S. (1991).
-
-

writ of certiorari, out-of-time, is denied.

No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The second Interim Report of the Special Master is re-
ceived and ordered filed. Exceptions to this Report and the first In-
terim Report of the Special Master, with supporting briefs, may be
filed by the parties within 45 day. Replies thereto, if any, may be filed
within 30 days. The amici curiae may file Exceptions and replies within
the time allowed the parties. Further consideration of the motion of Ne-
braska for leave to file an amended petition is deferred to consideration
of the Exceptions and replies.

chusetts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hamp-
shire. The motion of Connecticut Office of Consumer Counsel for leave
to intervene is referred to the Special Master. The motion of United
Illuminating Company, et al. for leave to intervene is referred to the
Special Master. Justice Souter took no part in the consideration or deci-
sion of these motions.

pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until June 8,

to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this
Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the petition
for a writ of certiorari.

mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
