OPINIONS
No. 91-5771. Harold Ray Wade, Petitioner v. United States. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Souter.
No. 90-8466. David Riggins, Petitioner v. Nevada. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Nevada. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by
Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Thomas with whom Justice Scalia joins except as to Part II-A.
No. 91-126. Howard Wyatt, Petitioner v. Bill Cole and John Rob-
bins, II. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice
Kennedy with whom Justice Scalia joins. Dissenting opinion by the
Chief Justice with whom Justice Souter and Justice Thomas join.
No. 90-5844. Terry Foucha, Petitioner v. Louisiana. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Justice White delivered the opinion
of the Court except as to Part III. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Kennedy with whom the Chief Justice joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Thomas with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 19, 1992
765
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-7914. Jesus Romero, Petitioner v. Texas. The application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia and by
him referred to the Court is denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice Kennedy join. Justice
O'Connor would grant the application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, MAY 20, 1992
767
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-874. Jesus Romero, Jr., Applicant v. James A. Collins, Direc-
tor, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Black-
mun, Justice Stevens and Justice Kennedy would grant the application
for stay of execution.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 91-8336. Roger K. Coleman, Petitioner v. Charles E. Thompson,
Warden, et al. On application for stay of execution of sentence of death.
The application for stay of execution presented to the Chief Justice and
by him referred to the Court is denied. Opinion per curiam. Justice Ste-
vens concurs in the denial of a stay and would deny the petition for writ
of certiorari. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun. Justice Souter
would grant the application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, MAY 21, 1992
769
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-8341. Robert V. Black, Jr., Petitioner v. Texas. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor would grant the application for
stay of execution pending the disposition of the petition for a writ of
certiorari.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-8361. Robert V. Black, Jr., Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice Black-
mun, Justice Stevens, and Justice O'Connor would grant the application
for stay of execution pending the disposition of the petition for a writ of
certiorari.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1992
771
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 91-1514. Anne Arundel County Republican Central Committee,
et al., Appellants v. The State Administrative Board of Election Laws,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the District of
Maryland. The judgment is affirmed. Justice Stevens would note proba-
ble jurisdiction and set the case for oral argument.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-1084. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jeffrey Lee Greenspan.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1085. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald J. Kenney. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1090. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gerald J. Garner. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1091. In the Matter of Disbarment of Granville H. Crabtree,
Jr. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1092. In the Matter of Disbarment of Stephen John Devine.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1093. In the Matter of Disbarment of Alan E. Robbins. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1095. In the Matter of Disbarment of Adrian F. O'Bryan.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1126. In the Matter of Disbarment of John T. Martin. It is
ordered that John T. Martin, of Springfield, Missouri, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1127. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Dalton Whit-
nall. It is ordered that William Dalton Whitnall, of Ripon, Wisconsin,

772
TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1992
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1128. In the Matter of Disbarment of Carlos Alberto Rodri-
guez. It is ordered that Carlos Alberto Rodriguez, of Miami, Florida,
be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule
issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 111, Original. State of Delaware, Plaintiff v. State of New York.
The fee application dated March 27, 1992, submitted by the Special
Master in this action is approved, and payment shall be made to
"Thomas H. Jackson, Special Master" in the total amount of
$105,824.85. It is further ordered that the participating jurisdictions
shall bear these costs equally, with each jurisdiction which is a party or
which has a pending application to intervene at the date of this order
contributing an equal share. It is further ordered that each such juris-
diction may make payment either to the firm of Dickstein, Shapiro &
Morin, as coordinating counsel for this purpose, or may make payment
directly or via separate counsel to the Special Master. It is further or-
dered that payment of fees, costs, and expenses pursuant to this order
shall be due within forty-five (45) days from the date hereof.
No. 91-32. Sorbothane, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Shirley McQuil-
lan, et al. The motion of respondents to expedite consideration of the
petition for a writ of certiorari is denied. Justice Blackmun would grant
this motion.
No. 91-1270. Ann Richards, Governor of Texas, et al., Appellants v.
Louis Terrazas, et al. The motion of potential intervenors, Guadalupe
Mena, et al., for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The
motion of Guadalupe Mena, et al., for leave to intervene is denied.
No. 91-7497. Herbert P. Russell, Petitioner v. Anthony M. Frank,
Postmaster General. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 16, 1992,
within which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to sub-
mit a petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 91-1229. United States By and Through Internal Revenue Ser-
vice, Petitioner v. Bruce J. McDermott, et al. Petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
granted.

773

Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for

petition.

No. 91-1382. The Shubert Organization, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Landmarks Preservation Commission of the City of New York, et al.
The motion of Real Estate Board of New York, Inc. for leave to file a
brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of Pacific Legal Founda-
tion for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the Appellate Division, Supreme Court of New
York, First Judicial Department, denied.
No. 91-1417. Harry K. Singletary, Secretary, Department of Cor-
rections of Florida, Petitioner v. Omar Blanco. The motion of respond-
ent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit denied.
No. 91-1595. Jay H. Glasser, Petitioner v. A. H. Robins Company,
Inc., et al. The motion of Dalkon Shield Alliance for Justice for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
No. 91-1597. Pennsylvania, Petitioner v. Karl S. Chambers. The
motion of Institute in Basic Life Principles for leave to file a brief as
amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Pennsylvania, Middle District, denied.
No. 91-6658. Larry Kinder, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White.
No. 91-7470. Larry Wilson, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit denied. Justice White would grant certiorari.

OPINIONS
No. 90-6105. John H. Evans, Jr., Petitioner v., United States. On
writ if certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by
Justice O'Connor concurring in part and concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas with whom the Chief
Justice and Justice Scalia join.
No. 91-194. Quill Corporation, Petitioner v. North Dakota By and
Through Its Tax Commissioner, Heidi Heitkamp. On writ of certiorari
to the Supreme Court of North Dakota. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsist-
ent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion
by Justice Scalia concurring in part and concurring in the judgment
with whom Justice Kennedy and Justice Thomas join. Opinion by Jus-
tice White concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 91.42. United States, Petitioner v. Therese A. Burke, Cynthia
R. Center, and Linda G. Gibbs. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment reversed and
case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Jus-
tice Souter concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O'Connor with whom Justice Thomas joins.
No. 90-1056. Charles W. Burson, Attorney General and Reporter for
Tennessee, Petitioner v. Mary Rebecca Freeman. On writ of certiorari

784
TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1992
to the Supreme Court of Tennessee, Middle Division. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Justice Blackmun
announced the judgment of the Court and deliversed an opinion in
which the Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice Kennedy join. Con-
curring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice Scalia concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens with whom
Justice O'Connior and Justice Souter join.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 1, 1992
791
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1615. Jesse Turner, et al., Appellants v. Arkansas, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Eastern District of
Arkansas. The judgment is affirmed. Justice White and Justice Black-
mun would note probable jurisdiction and set the case for oral
argument.
CERTIFIED QUESTION
No. 91-1841. In Re Bob Slagle. The certificate from the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit is dismissed. See Supreme
Court Rule 19.3; Wisniewski v. United States, 353 U.S. 901 (1957).
Opinion by Justice White regarding dismissal with whom Justice Black-
mun and Justice Stevens join.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. . Jane Doe, Petitioner v. United States. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to file a petition for a writ of certiorari under seal is
denied. Petitioner may file a redacted petition for a writ of certiorari on
or before June 19, 1992.
No. D-1089. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce D. Wellman. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1096. In the Matter of Disbarment of Max Carleton Garrick,
Jr. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1102. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kurt R. Conner. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D–1107. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert B. Chatz. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1129. In the Matter of Disbarment of David Paul Smith. It is
ordered that David Paul Smith, of Englewood, Colorado, be suspended

792
MONDAY, JUNE 1, 1992
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1130. In the Matter of Disbarment of James R. Bandy. It is
ordered that James R. Bandy, of River Rouge, Michigan, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 65, Original. Texas, Plaintiff v. New Mexico. The motion of the
River Master for approval of fees and expenses is granted and the
River Master is awarded $4,208.44 for the period January 1-March 31,
1992, to be paid equally by the parties.
No. 91-794. Henry Harper, et al., Petitioners v. Virginia Depart-
ment of Taxation. The order granting certiorari entered on May 18,
1992, is amended to read as follows: The petition for a writ of certiorari
is granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition.
No. 91-1780. Colorado, Petitioner v. John Harvey Gaskins. The
application for stay addressed to Justice Scalia and referred to the
Court is denied.
No. 91-1862. David Gantt, etc., et al., Appellants v. Dean Skelos,
etc. et al. The motion of appellants to expedite consideration of the ap-
peal is denied.
No. 91-7925. Morris Yagow, Petitioner v. Verna Musich, et al. The
motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied.
Petitioner is allowed until June 22, 1992, within which to pay the doc-
keting fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance
with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald
Co., Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in
forma pauperis.
APPEAL JURISDICTION NOTED
No. 91-1618. George Voinovich, Governor of Ohio, et al., Appellants
v. Barney Quilter, Speaker Pro Tempore of Ohio House of Represent-
atives, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Ohio. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted.

No. 90-6315. Ricky Perez, Petitioner v. Louisiana. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Louisiana denied. Justice Black-
mun, Justice O'Connor and Justice Souter would grant the petition, va-
cate the judgment and remand the case to the Supreme Court of Louisi-
ana for further consideration in light of Foucha v. Louisiana, 503 U.S.
(1992).
No. 91-1410. Samuel E. Waller, Petitioner v. United States. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice White with whom
Justice O'Connor joins.
No. 91-1447. Wanda Mae Bingham, Petitioner v. Inland Division of
General Motors. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit denied. Justice Blackmun would
grant the petition, vacate the judgment and remand the case to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of the 1991 Amendments to Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(c).

The Court will take a recess from Monday, June 1, 1992, until Mon-
day, June 8, 1992.

OPINIONS
No. 90–1604. Dan Morales, Attorney General of Texas, Petitioner v.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed in
part, reversed in part, injunction vacated, and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice

MONDAY, JUNE 1, 1992
805
Stevens with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Blackmun join. Jus-
tice Souter took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 91–636. Fort Gratiot Sanitary Landfill, Inc., Petitioner v. Michi-
gan Department of Natural Resources, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Stevens. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice
Blackmun joins.
No. 91-471. Chemical Waste Management, Inc., Petitioner v. Guy
Hunt, Governor of Alabama, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Alabama. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the
Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opin-
ion of this Court, including consideration of the appropriate relief to pe-
titioner. Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by the Chief
Justice.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3, 1992
809
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91-8475. Kenneth Granviel, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition by
this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for
a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall con-
tinue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1992
811
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Sou-
ter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-734. Northwest Airlines, Inc., Petitioner v. William D.
West. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Morales v. Trans World Airlines, Inc., 504 U.S.
(1992).
No. 91-6762. Danny K. Corley, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of Wil-
liams v. United States, 503 U.S. (1992).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-1097. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce Alan Friedman.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1098. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Thomas Ken-
ney. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1099. In the Matter of Disbarment of Henry Clay Hart, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1101. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mark Temple Watson.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1106. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard Horowitz.
Howard Horowitz, of Coral Gables, Florida, having requested to resign
as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to practice before the Bar

812
MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1992
of this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, heretofore issued on April 6,
1992, is hereby discharged.
No. D-1108. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Franklin Rosch.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1131. In the Matter of Disbarment of James R. Britton. It is
ordered that James R. Britton, of Bismarck, North Dakota, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1132. In the Matter of Disbarment of Marvin L. Kaiser. It is
ordered that Marvin L. Kaiser, of Williston, North Dakota, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1133. In the Matter of Disbarment of Vincent Thomas Sny-
der. It is ordered that Vincent Thomas Snyder, of Philadelphia, Penn-
sylvania, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1134. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Yutaka Kimura.
It is ordered that Robert Yutaka Kimura, of Honolulu, Hawaii, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1135. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arthur J. Piken. It is
ordered that Arthur J. Piken, of Kew Gardens, New York, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D–1136. In the Matter of Disbarment of Valentine Fraser Par-
ker. It is ordered that Valentine Fraser Parker, of Huntington, New
York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1137. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Cahn. It is or-
dered that William Cahn, of Tido Beach, New York, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

No. 90-985. Jayne Bray, et al., Petitioners 2. Alexandria Women's
Health Clinic, et al. This case is restored to the calendar for reargu-
ment.
No. 91-453. David H. Lucas, Petitioner v. South Carolina Coastal
Council. The motion of National Growth Management Leadership Proj-
ect, et al. to withdraw Chesapeake Bay Foundation from the list of
members joining its amicus curiae brief is granted.
No. 91-871. Bath Iron Works Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Di-
rector, Office of Workers' Compensation Programs, etc., et al. The mo-
tion of the Solicitor General for divided argument is granted.
No. 91-1075. George Lewis Bailes, Jr., Petitioner v. United States.
The motion of petitioner for costs and fees is denied.
No. 91-1521. United States, Petitioner v. Lowell Green. The motion
of the Solicitor General to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 91-1671. William J. Mertens, Alex W. Bandrowski, James A.
Clark, and Russell Franz, Petitioners v. Hewitt Associates. The Solici
tor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views of
the United States.
No. 91-1863. Raymond I. Klagiss, Petitioner v. Indiana. The applica-
tion for stay addressed to Justice Blackmun and referred to the Court is
denied.
No. 91-7328. Leonel Torres Herrera, Petitioner v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argu-
ment as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 91-7758. In Re Burton R. Landes, Petitioner. The motion of pe-
titioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Petitioner is
allowed until June 29, 1992, within which to pay the docketing fee re-
quired by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33
of the Rules of this Court.
No. 91-7938. In Re Henk Visser, Petitioner. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule 39.8.
Petitioner is allowed until June 29, 1992, within which to pay the doc-
keting fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance
with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of mandamus.
No. 91-8013. Rosemarie Clampitt, Petitioner v. Interinsurance Ex-
change, et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis is denied. Petitioner is allowed until June 29, 1992, within

814
MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1992
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court.

No. 90-1606. Attorney General of California, et al., Petitioners v.
Trans World Airlines, Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denied. Justice
Blackmun would grant certiorari. Justice Souter took no part in the
consideration or decision of this petition.
No. 91-142. Tidewater Marine Service, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Lloyd W. Aubry, Jr., et al. The motion of Maritime Law Association of
the United States for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 91-349. Pacific Merchant Shipping Association, et al., Petition-
ers v. Lloyd W. Aubry, Jr., Labor Commissioner, Division of Labor
Standards Enforcement, Department of Industrial Relations of Califor-
nia. The motion of American Waterways Operators, Inc. for leave to
file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 91-502. Public Utilities Commission of California, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Federal Express Corporation. The motion of California
Trucking Association for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is
granted. The motion of International Brotherhood of Teamsters for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae is granted. The motion of National
Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae is granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.
No. 91-1426. California, Petitioner v. Stephen Ross Harden. The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeal of California, Sixth
Appellate District, denied.
No. 91-1519. Vincent F. Costello, Petitioner v. Thomas A. McEn-
ery, etc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit denied. Justice White would grant
certiorari.
No. 91-1672. Biodex Corporation, Petitioner v. Loredan Biomedical,
Inc., et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Federal Circuit denied. Justice White would grant cer-
tiorari.
No. 91-7972. Nadia D. Jones, Petitioner v. AT&T Technologies,
Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fourth Circuit denied. Justice O'Connor took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this petition.

MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1992
COMMON LAW CERTIORARI DENIED
823
No. 91-1709. In Re Jacqueline Mills, Petitioner. The petition for a
common law writ of certiorari and/or mandamus is denied.
HABEAS CORPUS DENIED
No. 91-8281. In Re Kwoh Cheng Sun, Petitioner. The petition for
writ of habeas corpus is denied.
MANDAMUS DENIED
No. 91-7876. In Re Robert Kaltenbach, Petitioner;
No. 91-7943. In Re Marvin Crenshaw, Petitioner; and
No. 91-8067. In Re Nicholas Bachynsky, Petitioner. The petitions
for writs of mandamus are denied.
REHEARINGS DENIED
No. 91-1405. Optimal Data Corporation, Petitioner v. United
States;
No. 91-1457. Bernie Piotrowski, et al., Petitioner v. City of Chicago;
No. 91-7026. Joseph E. Covillion, Petitioner v. Aetna Life & Casu-
alty, et al.;
No. 91-7264. In Re Ronald W. Jarvi, Petitioner;
No. 91-7298. Lonnie Wickliffe, Petitioner v. James Aiken, Commis-
sioner, Indiana Department of Correction, et al.;
No. 91-7520. James T. Fite, Petitioner v. Phillip Cantrell, et al.; and
No. 91-7532. Oscar A. Meyer, Petitioner v. Anna D. Meyer; and Os-
car A. Meyer, Petitioner v. Anna D. Meyer. The petitions for rehearing
are denied.

The Court will take a recess from Monday, June 8, 1992, until Friday,
June 12, 1992.

OPINIONS
No. 91-164. United States, Petitioner v. Thompson/Center Arms
Company. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Justice Souter announced
the judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in which the Chief
Justice and Justice O'Connor join. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring
in the judgment with whom Justice Thomas joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice White with whom Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, and Jus-
tice Kennedy join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-5843. Dennis Sochor, Petitioner v. Florida. On writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Judgment vacated and case re-
manded to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Concurring
opinion by Justice O'Connor. Opinion by the Chief Justice concurring in
part and dissenting in part with whom Justice White and Justice

MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1992
829
Thomas join. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and dissent-
ing in part with whom Justice Blackmun joins. Opinion by Justice Scalia
concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 90-1029. Eastman Kodak Company, Petitioner v. Image Tech-
nical Services, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with whom Jus-
tice O'Connor and Justice Thomas join.
No. 91-535. Alan B. Burdick, Petitioner v. Morris Takushi, Director
of Elections of Hawaii, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by
Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Kennedy with whom Jus-
tice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join.

Dover, NJ
Judge Peter J.
Wauters
Giovine
Adjourned until Friday, June 12, 1992, at 10 o'clock.
833

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JUNE 12. 1992
835
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91–779. Burlington Northern Railroad Company, Petitioner v.
William D. Ford and Thomas L. Johnson. On writ of certiorari to the
Supreme Court of Montana. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Souter.
No. 91-72. Federal Trade Commission, Petitioner v. Ticor Title In-
surance Company, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment reversed and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring
opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with
whom Justice O'Connor and Justice Thomas join. Dissenting opinion by
Justice O'Connor with whom Justice Thomas joins.
No. 90-1424. Manuel Lujan, Jr., Secretary of the Interior, Petitioner
v. Defenders of Wildlife, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Justice Scalia announced the judgment of
the Court and delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts
I, II, III-A, and IV, and an opinion with respect to Part III-B with
whom the Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice Thomas join. Opin-
ion by Justice Kennedy concurring in part and concurring in the judg-
ment with whom Justice Souter joins. Opinion by Justice Stevens con-
curring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun with
whom Justice O'Connor joins.
No. 91-763. Republic of Argentina and Banco Central de la
Republica Argentina, Petitioners v. Weltover, Inc., et al. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
Adjourned until Monday, June 15, 1992, at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 15, 1992
837
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-7295. Joe Dale Kyle, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is va-
cated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit for further consideration in light of United States
v. Shano, 955 F. 2d 291 (CA5 1992) (withdrawing United States v.
Shano, 947 F. 2d 1263 (CA5 1991)) and United States Sentencing Com-
mission, Guidelines Manual, Sec. 4B1.2, comment., n. 2 (Nov. 1991).
The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy and Justice Thomas
dissent.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-894. Intercontinental Life Insurance Company, Applicant v.
Lou R. Lindblom. The application for stay presented to Justice Ken-
nedy and by him referred to the Court is denied. Justice O'Connor
would grant the application.
No. D-1103. In the Matter of Disbarment of Newton Alfred Winn.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1109. In the Matter of Disbarment of Daniel V. Presnick.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1111. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harvey Tessler. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1114. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gladys E. Harrison.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1115. In the Matter of Disbarment of John B. D'Albora. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1138. In the Matter of Disbarment of Winston W. Jacobo. It
is ordered that Winston W. Jacobo, of St. Augustine, Florida, be sus-

838
MONDAY, JUNE 15, 1992
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1139. In the Matter of Disbarment of David M. Fine. It is or-
dered that David M. Fine, of Richmond, Virginia, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1140. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Joseph Fitzpat-
rick. It is ordered that James Joseph Fitzpatrick, of Portsmouth, New
Hampshire, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court. Justice Souter took no part in the consideration or decision of
this order.
No. 108, Original. State of Nebraska, Plaintiff v. States of Wyoming
and Colorado. The Court by order dated April 20, 1992, awarded the
Special Master interim compensation and reimbursement of expenses
and it is ordered that the award is to be paid as follows: Colorado,
$25,000.00; the four proposed intervenors/amici curiae, $5,000.00 each;
the remaining award to be paid 40% by Nebraska, 40% by Wyoming,
20% by United States. See printed statement. Statement by Justice
White. Dissenting statement by Justice Stevens.
No. 119, Original. State of Connecticut, Commonwealth of Massa-
chusetts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hamp-
shire. The First Interim Report of the Special Master is received and
ordered filed. The Recommendations of the Special Master are adopted.
It is ordered that the motion of Connecticut Office of Consumer Counsel
for leave to intervene is denied. It is further ordered that the motion of
the United Illuminating Company, New England Power Company, the
Connecticut Light & Power Company, Canal Electric Company, Mon-
taup Electric Company, and Taunton Municipal Lighting Plant for
leave to intervene is granted. The defendant is allowed 20 days within
which to file and serve its answer to the complaint of the intervening
plaintiffs. Justice Souter took no part in the consideration or decision of
these orders.
No. 91-10. Spectrum Sports, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Shirley
McQuillan, et vir, dba Sorboturf Enterprises. The motion of the Solici-
tor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae
and for divided argument is granted.

MONDAY, JUNE 15, 1992
839
No. 91-882. Lawrence E. Lewy, et al., Petitioners . Virginia De-

for a writ of certiorari is denied.
No. 91-1030. Pamela Withrow, Petitioner v. Robert Allen Williams,

ment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Ricky B. Medlock, Es-

respondent in this case.
No. 91-1420. Joan Growe, Secretary of State of Minnesota, et al.,
Appellants v. James Emison, et al. The motion of Martin Frost, et al.
for leave to file a brief as amici curiae is granted.

OPINIONS
No. 91-615. Allied-Signal, Inc., as Successor-In-Interest to The
Bendix Corporation, Petitioner v. Director, Division of Taxation. On
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of New Jersey. Judgment re-
versed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor with whom the Chief
Justice, Justice Blackmun, and Justice Thomas join.
No. 91–913. John R. Patterson, Trustee, Petitioner v. Joseph B. Shu-
mate, Jr. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia.
No. 91-367. Carol Ankenbrandt, as Next Friend and Mother of L. R.
and S. R., Petitioner v. Jon A. Richards and Debra Kesler. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals for fur-

854
MONDAY, JUNE 15, 1992
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice White. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judg-
ment Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment with
whom Justice Thomas joins.
No. 91-5118. Derrick Morgan, Petitioner v. Illinois. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Judgment reversed with re-
spect to the death sentence and case remanded to the Supreme Court
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice White. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia with
whom the Chief Justice and Justice Thomas join.
No. 91-712. United States, Petitioner v. Humberto Alvarez-
Machain. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court
of Appeals for further proceeding in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by the Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor join.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JUNE 18, 1992
859
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
No. 90-1676. Mary Gade, Director, Illinois Environmental Protec-
tion Agency, Petitioner v. National Solid Wastes Management Associa-
tion. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Justice O'Connor announced the
judgment of the Court and delivered an opinion in Parts I, III, and IV
which represent the views of the Court, and Part II which is joined by
the Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice
Kennedy concurring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens, and Justice Thomas join.
No. 90-1918. Kraft General Foods, Inc., Petitioner v. Iowa Depart-
ment of Revenue and Finance. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Iowa. Judgmemt reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Jus-
tice with whom Justice Blackmun joins.
No. 91–372. Georgia, Petitioner v. Thomas McCollum, William Jo-
seph McCollum and Ella Hampton McCollum. On writ of certiorari to
the Supreme Court of Georgia. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Concurring opinion
by the Chief Justice. Opinion by Justice Thomas concurring in the judg-
ment. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Connor. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Scalia.
No. 90-1912. Stephanie Nordlinger, Petitioner v. Kenneth Hahn, in
His Capacity as Tax Assessor for Los Angeles County, et al. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Blackmun. Opinion by Justice Thomas con-
curring in part and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens.
CAZ
affid
Adjourned until tomorrow at 10 o'clock.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JUNE 19, 1992
861
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91-542. Ellis B. Wright, Jr., Warden and Mary Sue Terry, At-
torney General of Virginia, Petitioners v. Frank Robert West, Jr. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Justice Thomas announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an
opinion with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join. Opinion by
Justice White concurring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice O'Connor
concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice
Stevens join. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Souter concurring in the judgment.
No. 91-872. United States, Petitioner v. Anthony Salerno, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of Appeals
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice Blackmun.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
No. 91-594. American National Red Cross, Petitioner v. S.G. and
A.E. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
First Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia
with whom The Chief Justice, Justice O'Connor, and Justice Kennedy
join.
No. 91–119. Wisconsin Department of Revenue, Petitioner v. Wil-
liam Wrigley, Jr., Co. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Wisconsin. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme
Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concur-
ring in Parts I and II, and concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Kennedy with whom the Chief Justice and Justice Black-
mun join.

862
FRIDAY, JUNE 19, 1992
No. 91-543. New York, Petitioner v. United States, et al.;
No. 91-558. County of Allegany, New York, Petitioner v. United
States, et al.; and
No. 91-563. County of Cortland, New York, Petitioner v. United
States, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Second Circuit. Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in
part, and cases remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
O'Connor. Opinion by Justice White concurring in part and dissenting
in part with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join. Opinion
by Justice Stevens concurring in part and dissenting in part.
No. 91-538. Forsyth County, Georgia, Petitioner v. The Nationalist
Movement. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Black-
mun. Dissenting opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice White,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Thomas join.
Adjourned until Monday, June 22, 1992, at 10 o'clock.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-954. Harry L. Reynolds, Jr., Applicant v. International Ama-
teur Athletic Federation, et al. The motion of the Athletics Congress of
the U.S.A., Inc. to vacate the stay entered by Justice Stevens is
denied.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 22, 1992
865
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
APPEAL SUMMARY DISPOSITION
-
No. 91–962. Cynthia Harris, Appellant v. City of Birmingham, et al.
Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern District
of Alabama. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States District Court for the Northern District of Alabama with
instructions to dismiss the appeal as moot. United States v. Munsing-
wear, Inc., 340 U.S. 36 (1950).
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-505. William West, Petitioner v. Northwest Airlines, Inc.
Upon consideration of the petition for rehearing, the order entered
June 8, 1992, denying the petition for a writ of certiorari is vacated. The
petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case
is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit for further consideration in light of Morales v. Trans World Air-
lines, 504 U.S. — (1992).
No. 91-670. United States, Petitioner v. Rene Martin Verdugo-
Urquidez. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of United States v. Alvarez-Machain, 504 U.S.
(1992).
-
No. 91-1269. U. S. Metroline Services, Inc., Petitioner v. South-
western Bell Telephone Company. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition
for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Federal Trade Commission v. Ticor

866
MONDAY, JUNE 22, 1992
Title Insurance Company, 504 U.S.
· -
(1992). Justice O'Connor took
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 91-1527. The Ohio Public Employees Deferred Compensation
Program, Petitioner v. Marvin A. Sicherman, Trustee. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is
vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Patterson v.
Shumate, 504 U.S. - (1992).
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-1112. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ivan Vance White, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1113. In the Matter of Disbarment of Hilton Davis. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-1141. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert M. Ellis. It is
ordered that Robert M. Ellis, of Wilmette, Illinois, be suspended from
the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable within
forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 119, Original. State of Connecticut, Commonwealth of Massa-
chusetts and State of Rhode Island, Plaintiffs v. State of New Hamp-
shire. The motion of Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Com-
pany for leave to participate as amicus curiae in this case is granted.
Justice Souter took no part in the consideration or decision of this
motion.
No. 91-535. Alan B. Burdick, Petitioner v. Morris Takushi, Director
of Elections of Hawaii, et al. The motion of respondents for taxation of
respondents' costs in printing joint appendix is granted.
No. 91-7358. Todd A. Brecht, Petitioner v. Gordon A. Abrahamson,
Superintendent, Dodge Correctional Institution. The motion for ap-
pointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that Allen E. Shoen-
berger, Esquire, of Chicago, Illinois, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the petitioner in this case.
No. 91-7873. William Fex, Petitioner v. Michigan. The motion for
appointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that John B. Payne,
Jr., Esquire, of Dearborn, Michigan, is appointed to serve as counsel
for the petitioner in this case.
No. 91-8092. Donald W. Doerr, Petitioner v. Eva A. Doerr. The mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. Peti-

MONDAY, JUNE 22, 1992
867
tioner is allowed until July 13, 1992, within which to pay the docketing
fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Justice Ste-
vens, dissenting: For the reasons expressed in Brown v. Herald Co.,
Inc., 464 U.S. 928 (1983), we would deny the petition for a writ of cer-
tiorari without reaching the merits of the motion to proceed in forma
pauperis.
No. 91-8173. James L. Martin, Petitioner v. Delaware. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule
39.8. Petitioner is allowed until July 13, 1992, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of certiorari.
CERTIORARI GRANTED
No. 91-1353. Thomas F. Conroy, Petitioner v. Walter Aniskoff, Jr.,
et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial Court of
Maine granted.
No. 91-1657. Charlene Leatherman, et al., Petitioners v. Tarant
County Narcotics Intelligence and Coordination Unit, et al. Petition for

ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice

Justice Blackmun and Justice O'Connor join, and with whom Justice
Stevens joins except as to Part I(A). Opinion by Justice Blackmun con-
curring in the judgment. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the
judgment with whom Justice White and Justice Blackmun join as to
Part I.

the Fifth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by the Chief Justice.
Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in the judgment. Opinion by

mun and Justice O'Connor join.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 24, 1992
889
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 90-857. Marc Gilbert Doggett, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Court of
Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice O'Con-
nor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Thomas with whom the Chief Justice.
and Justice Scalia join.
No. 90-1014. Robert E. Lee, Individually and as Principal of Nathan
Bishop Middle School, et al., Petitioners v. Daniel Weisman, etc. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring
opinion by Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Stevens and Justice
O'Connor join. Concurring opinion by Justice Souter with whom Justice
Stevens and Justice O'Connor join. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia
with whom the Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice Thomas join.
No. 91-810. City of Burlington, Petitioner v. Ernest Dague, Sr., et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment reversed in part and case remanded to the
Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Blackmun with whom Justice Stevens joins. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice O'Connor.
No. 90–1038. Thomas Cipollone, Individually and as Executor of the
Estate of Rose D. Cipollone, Petitioner v. Liggett Group, Inc., et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit. Judgment reversed in part, affirmed in part, and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Justice Stevens delivered the opinion of
the Court except as to Parts V and VI. Opinion by Justice Blackmun
concurring in part, concurring in the judgment in part, and dissenting
in part with whom Justice Kennedy and Justice Souter join. Opinion by
Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part
with whom Justice Thomas joins.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JUNE 26, 1992
891
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Justice White, Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, Justice
O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, and Justice
Thomas.
OPINIONS
No. 91-1502. Barbara Franklin, Secretary of Commerce, et al., Ap-
pellants v. Massachusetts, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Massachusetts. Judgment reversed and case
remanded to the District Court for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Justice O'Connor delivered the opinion of
the Court except as to Part III. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring
in part and concurring in the judgment with whom Justice Blackmun,
Justice Kennedy, and Justice Souter join. Opinion by Justice Scalia con-
curring in part and concurring in the judgment.
No. 91-155. International Society for Krishna Consciousness, Inc.,
and Brian Rumbaugh, Petitioners v. Walter Lee, Superintendent of
Port Authority Police. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment sustaining the ban on so-
licitation in Port Authority terminals is affirmed. Opinion by the Chief
Justice announced by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice
O'Connor in this case and concurring in the judgment in No. 91-339,
post. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the judgment in this
case with whom Justice Blackmun, Justice Stevens, and Justice join as
to Part I and in No. 91-339, post. Opinion by Justice Souter concurring
in the judgment in No. 91-339, post, and dissenting in this case with
whom Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join.
No. 91–339. Walter Lee, Superintendent of Port Authority Police,
Petitioner v. International Society for Krishna Consciousness, Inc., et
al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Second Circuit. Judgment holding that the ban on distribution of litera-
ture in the Port Authority airport terminals is invalid under the First
Amendment is affirmed. Opinion per curiam announced by Justice
O'Connor. Opinion by Justice O'Connor concurring in the judgment in
this case and concurring in No. 91-155, ante. Opinion by Justice Ken-
nedy concurring in the judgment in this case and concurring in the judg-
ment in No. 91–155, ante, with whom Justice Blackmun, Justice Ste-
vens and Justice Souter join as to Part I. Opinion by Justice Souter

892
FRIDAY, JUNE 26. 1992
concurring in the judgment in this case and dissenting in No. 91-155,
ante, with whom Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens join. Dissenting
opinion by the Chief Justice with whom Justice White, Justice Scalia,
and Justice Thomas join.
No. 90-1205. United States, Petitioner v. Kirk Fordice, Governor of
Mississippi, et al.; and
No. 90-6588. Jake Ayers, et al., Petitioners v. Kirk Fordice, Gover-
nor of Mississippi, et al. On writs of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment vacated and the cases
are remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings in con-
formity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice White. Con-
curring opinion by Justice O'Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice
Thomas. Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment in part
and dissenting in part.
No. 91-971. Two Pesos, Inc., Petitioner v. Taco Cabana, Inc. On writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice White. Concurring opinion by
Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in the judgment.
Opinion by Justice Thomas concurring in the judgment.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JUNE 29, 1992
897
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
The Chief Justice said:
"Today's orders of the Court have been certified by the Chief Justice,
filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally."
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. 91-7390. Henry Jose Espinosa, Petitioner v. Florida. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. Judgment reversed and case remanded
to the Supreme Court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. The Chief Justice and Justice
White dissent and would grant certiorari and set the case down for oral
argument. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia.
APPEALS-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 91-1270. Ann Richards, Governor of Texas, et al., Appellants v.
Louis Terrazas, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for
the Western District of Texas. The judgment is affirmed.
No. 91-1571. Massachusetts, et al., Appellants v. Barbara Franklin,
Secretary of Commerce, et al. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the District of Massachusetts. The cross-appeal is dismissed.
CERTIORARI-SUMMARY DISPOSITION
No. 90-1473. Joanne Kotler, Individually and as Administratrix of
the Estate of George P. Kotler, Petitioner v. American Tobacco Com-
pany, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the First Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit for further consid-
eration in light of Cipollone v. Liggett Group, Inc., 505 U.S.
(1992).
No. 90–1837. Minas H. Papas, et ux., Petitioners v. Zoecon Corpora-
tion. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit. The petition for writ of certiorari is

898
MONDAY, JUNE 29, 1992
granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Cipollone v. Liggett Group, Inc., 505 U.S.
(1992).
No. 91-310. Merritt E. Jones, et al., Petitioners 2. Clear Creek In-
dependent School District. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. The petition for
writ of certiorari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Lee v. Weisman, 505 U.S.
(1992).
No. 91-1646. Antares Aircraft L.P., Petitioner v. Federal Republic
of Nigeria, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The petition for writ of certio-
rari is granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further
consideration in light of Republic of Argentina v. Weltover, Inc., 504
U.S. (1992).
No. 91-5450. James Ernest Hitchcock, Petitioner v. Florida. The pe-
tition for rehearing is granted. The order entered October 15, 1991, de-
nying the petition for a writ of certiorari is vacated. The motion of peti-
tioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for a writ
of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is re-
manded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in
light of Espinosa v. Florida, 505 U.S. - (1992). Justice Thomas took
-
no part in the consideration or decision of this case.
No. 91-6076. Mauricio Beltran-Lopez, Petitioner v. Florida. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. The motion
of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for
writ of certiorari are granted. The judgment is vacated and the case is
remanded to the Supreme Court of Florida for further consideration in
light of Espinosa v. Florida, 505 U.S. (1992).
No. 91-6887. David Aguirre, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted. The judg-
ment is vacated and the case is remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Dog-
gett v. United States, 505 U.S.
(1992).

Shaughnessy. It is ordered that Robert William Shaughnessy, of
Miami, Florida, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and
that a rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show
cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this
Court.

MONDAY, JUNE 29, 1992

suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
.No. 91-1546. Bob Slagle, Chairman, Texas Democratic Party, Appel-
lant v. Louis Terrazas, et al. The motion of appellant for establishment
of deadline for submission of the views of the United States is denied.
No. 91-8233. In Re Robert Kaltenbach, Petitioner. The motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is denied. See Rule
39.8. Petitioner is allowed until July 20, 1992, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of mandamus.
No. 91-8412. Darrell Prows, Petitioner v. J. D. Williams, Warden,
et al. The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
denied. See Rule 39.8. Petitioner is allowed until July 20, 1992, within
which to pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a
petition in compliance with Rule 33 of the Rules of this Court. Justice
Blackmun and Justice Stevens would deny the petition for a writ of
certiorari.

RECESS ORDER
The Court will take a recess from today until the first Monday in Oc-
tober, 1992, at which time the October, 1991 Term will adjourn.
OPINIONS
No. 91–453. David H. Lucas, Petitioner v. South Carolina Coastal
Council. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Judgment reversed and case remanded to the Supreme Court for fur-
ther proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opin-
ion by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice Kennedy concurring in the
judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Blackmun. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens. Statement by Justice Souter.

916
MONDAY, JUNE 29, 1992
No. 91-744. Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania, et
al., Petitioners v. Robert P. Casey, et al., etc.; and
No. 91-902. Robert P. Casey, et al., etc., Petitioners v. Planned Par-
enthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania, et al. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. The judgment
in No. 91-902 is affirmed. The judgment in No. 91-744 is affirmed in
part, reversed in part and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals.
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court, in-
cluding consideration of the question of severability. Justice O'Connor,
Justice Kennedy, and Justice Souter announced the judgment of the
Court and delivered the opinion of the Court with respect to Parts I, II,
III, V-A, V-C, and VI, an opinion with respect to Part V-E, in which
Justice Stevens joins, and an opinion with respect to Parts IV, V-B,
and V-D. Opinion by Justice Stevens concurring in part and dissenting
in part. Opinion by Justice Blackmun concurring in part, concurring in
the judgment in part, and dissenting in part. Opinion by the Chief Jus-
tice concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part with
whom Justice White, Justice Scalia, and Justice Thomas join. Opinion
by Justice Scalia concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in
part with whom the Chief Justice, Justice White, and Justice Thomas
join.
The Chief Justice said:
"I am authorized to announce that all cases submitted to the Court
for decision have been acted upon by the Court. Accordingly, it is or-
dered that those cases remaining on the docket, but not ready for con-
sideration, are continued to the session of the Court beginning October
5, 1992. The Court will be in recess from today until the first Monday in
October, 1992, at which time the October 1991 Term of the Court will
be adjourned and the October 1992 Term of the Court will begin as pro-
vided by statute on the first Monday in October. In closing, on behalf of
each Justice, I thank each member of the Supreme Court staff for their
continued dedication to the work of the Court during the Term. This
dedication and its attendant professionalism is recognized by the Bar
and the public. Such dedicated service makes the heavy workload of the
Court much easier for each member of the Court."

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JULY 13. 1992
917
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 92-5088. David Lee Holland, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the
disposition by this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted,
this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judgment of
this Court.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JULY 16, 1992
919
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice.Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-32. T. K. Wetherell, Speaker of the Florida House of Repre-
sentatives, et al., Applicants v. Miguel De Grandy, et al. The applica-
tion for stay presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the
Court is granted and it is ordered that the judgment of the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Florida, filed July 2,
1992, in case Nos. 92-40015-WS, 92-40131-WS, and 92-40220-WS, is
stayed pending the timely filing of a statement as to jurisdiction.
Should such a statement be timely filed, this order is to remain in effect
pending this Court's action on the appeal. In the event the judgment is
affirmed, or the appeal is dismissed, this order is to terminate automat-
ically. Should jurisdiction be noted or postponed, or should the judg-
ment be summarily vacated or reversed, this order is to remain in effect
pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

(JOURNAL)
FRIDAY, JULY 17, 1992
921
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
OPINION PER CURIAM
No. A-40. Leona Benten, et al., Petitioners v. David Kessler, Com-
missioner, Food and Drug Administration, et al. On application to va-
cate stay. Petitioners' application to vacate the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit's July 15, 1992, stay pending respond-
ents' appeal, presented to Justice Thomas and by him referred to the
Court, is denied. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting statement by Justice
Blackmun. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-51. T. K. Wetherell, Speaker of the Florida House of Repre-
sentatives, et al., Applicants v. Miguel De Grandy, et al. The applica-
tion for stay presented to Justice Kennedy and by him referred to the
Court is granted and it is ordered that the order of the United States
District Court for the Northern District of Florida, dated July 16, 1992,
in case Nos. 92-40015-WS, 92-40131-WS, and 92-40220-WS, is stayed
pending the timely filing of a statement as to jurisdiction. Should such a
statement be timely filed, this order is to remain in effect pending this
Court's action on the appeal. In the event the judgment is affirmed, or
the appeal is dismissed, this order is to terminate automatically. Should
jurisdiction be noted or postponed, or should the judgment be sum-
marily vacated or reversed, this order is to remain in effect pending the
sending down of the judgment of this Court. Justice White took no part
in the consideration or decision of this application.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, JULY 20, 1992
933
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice. Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
REHEARING DENIED
No. 91-8111. Edward D. Kennedy, Petitioner
Kennedy, Petitioner v. Harry K.
Singletary, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The
petition for rehearing is denied.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-5194. Edward D. Kennedy, Petitioner v. Harry K.
Singletary, Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections, et al. The
application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Jus-
tice Kennedy and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida is denied.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JULY 22, 1992
935
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice, Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-5248. Harold Joe Lane, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of
certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, JULY 28, 1992
937
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice. Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92–5239. William Andrews, Petitioner v. Utah. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice White
and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Utah is denied. Justice Blackmun
and Justice Stevens would grant the application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, JULY 29. 1992
939
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice. Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 92-5182. Carl Eugene Kelly, Petitioner v. Texas. The application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the disposition by
this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for
a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall con-
tinue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, JULY 30, 1992
941
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-5321. William Andrews, Petitioner v. Scott Carver, Warden,
Utah State Prison. The application for stay of execution of sentence of
death presented to Justice White and by him referred to the Court is
denied. The petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Jus-
tice Stevens would grant the application for stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)
SATURDAY, AUGUST 1, 1992
943
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-82. Gene McNary, Commissioner, Immigration and Natural-
ization Service, et al., Applicants, v. Haitian Centers Council, Inc., et
al. The application for stay, presented to Justice Thomas and by him
referred to the Court, is granted, and it is ordered that the judgment of
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, case
No. 92-6144, filed July 29, 1992, and the subsequent July 29, 1992,
order of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of
New York, case No. 92 CV 1258, are stayed pending the filing of a pe-
tition for a writ of certiorari on or before August 24, 1992. Should the
petition be filed on or before that date this order is to remain in effect
pending this Court's action on the petition. If the petition for a writ of
certiorari is denied, this order is to terminate automatically. In the
event the petition is granted, this order is to remain in effect pending
the sending down of the judgment of this Court. Should the Solicitor
General so file a petition for a writ of certiorari, respondents' response
is to be filed on or before September 8, 1992. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Blackmun with whom Justice Stevens joins.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, AUGUST 4, 1992
945
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-5208. Curtis Lee Johnson, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition
for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 5, 1992
947
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. A-82. Gene McNary, Commissioner, Immigration and Natural-
ization Service, et al. v. Haitian Centers Council, Inc., et al. The mo-
tion of respondents to treat the application for stay as a petition for a
writ of certiorari, grant the petition and set an expedited briefing
schedule is denied.
No. A-98. Frank X. Hopkins, Warden, Petitioner v. Harold Lamont
Otey. The application to vacate the stay of execution of sentence of
death entered by the United States District Court for the District of
Nebraska, presented to Justice Blackmun and by him referred to the
Court, is denied. The Chief Justice, Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas
would grant the application.

ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 91–1160. A. J. Arave, Warden, Petitioner v. Thomas E. Creech.
The order entered June 15, 1992, is amended to read as follows: "The
motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted.
The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted limited to Question 1 pre-
sented by the petition."

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES

Disbarment order entered.
