ment order entered.

Disbarment order entered.

ment order entered.
No. D-1123. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Jerome Houck.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1124. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce Allan Glubin.
Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1125. In the Matter of Disbarment of Richard C. Schulz. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D–1127. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Dalton Whit-
nall. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1128. In the Matter of Disbarment of Carlos Alberto Rodri-
guez. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1129. In the Matter of Disbarment of David Paul Smith. Dis-
barment order entered.
No. D-1136. In the Matter of Disbarment of Valentine Fraser
Parker. Disbarment order entered.
No. D-1137. In the Matter of Disbarment of William Cahn. Disbar-
ment order entered.
No. D-1140. In the Matter of Disbarment of James Joseph Fitzpat-
rick. Disbarment order entered. Justice Souter took no part in the con-
sideration or decision of this order.
No. D-1144. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Justin Driscoll.
It is ordered that Robert Justin Driscoll, of Denver, Colorado, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-

962
MONDAY, AUGUST 18, 1992
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1145. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth Van Rye. It is
ordered that Kenneth Van Rye, of Elmwood Park, New Jersey, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1146. In the Matter of Disbarment of Philip Richard Herzig.
It is ordered that Philip Richard Herzig, of Salina, Kansas, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1147. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jeffrey Michael Leben.
It is ordered that Jeffrey Michael Leben, of Yorktown Heights, New
York, be suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a
rule issue, returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause
why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1148. In the Matter of Disbarment of John P. Trevaskis, Jr.
It is ordered that John P. Trevaskis, Jr., of Media, Pennsylvania, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1149. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael I. Greenwald.
It is ordered that Michael I. Greenwald, of Cleveland, Ohio, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. 92-24. In Re James B. Bell, Petitioner. The application for stay
of enforcement of judgment addressed to Justice Thomas and referred
to the Court is denied.

peris is granted. The motion for leave to file a petition for rehearing is
denied.

ing is denied.

MONDAY, AUGUST 18, 1992
No. 91-1447. Wanda Bingham v. Inland Division of General Motors.
The petition for rehearing is denied. Justice Blackmun would call for a
response to the petition for rehearing.
ASSIGNMENT ORDER
An order of the Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice Mar-
shall (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit during the period of December 2-4,
1992, and for such time as may be required to complete unfinished busi-
ness, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec 294(a), is ordered entered on the min-
utes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. Sec. 295.

TUESDAY, AUGUST 25, 1992
965
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.

No. 92-265. In Re Daniel Vasquez, Warden and Daniel Lundgren,
Attorney General of California, Petitioners. The application for stay ad-
dressed to Justice Thomas and referred to the Court is denied.

(JOURNAL)
THURSDAY, AUGUST 27, 1992
967
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 92–253. Illinois Department of Corrections, Petitioner v. Marvin
Flowers. The application for stay addressed to the Chief Justice and re-
ferred to the Court is granted, and it is ordered that the mandate of the
United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, case Nos. 91-
2330 and 91-2415, is recalled and stayed pending the disposition by this
Court of the petition for writ of certiorari. Should the petition for writ
of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the event
the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue
pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court. Justice Black-
mun and Justice Stevens would deny the application for stay.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1992
969
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia Justice Kennedy, Jus-
tice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 90-985. Jayne Bray, et al. v. Alexandria Women's Health Clinic,
et al. The motion of respondents for leave to file a brief on reargument
is granted with respect to arguments addressing the potential signifi-
cance of Planned Parenthood v. Casey, 505 U. S. (1992), and the
availability of injunctive relief for violations of 42 U. S. C. Section
1985(3), but denied with respect to arguments adressing the hindrance.
clause of 42 U. S. C. Section 1985(3).
-
Petitioners may file a supplemental brief on reargument on or before
September 17, 1992, responding to respondents' arguments regarding
Planned Parenthood v. Casey, supra, and the availability of injunctive
relief.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Blackmun
joins. Justice O'Connor would grant the motion in its entirety.

ORDERS IN PENDING CASES
No. D-1150. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ronald E. Deutsch. It
is ordered that Ronald E. Deutsch, of Santa Fe, New Mexico, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1151. In the Matter of Disbarment of Harvin Cooper Moore,
III. It is ordered that Harvin Cooper Moore, III, of Houston, Texas, be
suspended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue,
returnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he
should not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D-1152. In the Matter of Disbarment of Larry Burton Bach. It
is ordered that Larry Burton Bach, of Dallas, Texas, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
No. D–1153. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert L. Kirkman. It
is ordered that Robert L. Kirkman, of Portland, Oregon, be suspended
from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, returnable
within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

is ordered that Oscar Buren Ladner, of Gulfport, Mississippi, be sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court and that a rule issue, re-
turnable within forty days, requiring him to show cause why he should
not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

not be disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

Mortgage Corporation for leave to participate in oral argument as ami-
cus curiae, for divided argument and for additional time for oral argu-
ment is denied.
No. 91–1030. Pamela Withrow, Petitioner v. Robert Allen Williams,
Jr. The motion of the Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral
argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument is granted.
No. 91-1393. A. L. Lockhart, Director, Arkansas Department of
Correction, Petitioner v. Bobby Ray Fretwell. The motion of the Solici-
tor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae
and for divided argument is granted.

Appellants v. James Emison, et al. The motion of the Solicitor General
for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for di-
vided argument is granted.
No. 91-1513. United States Department of the Treasury and Mitch-
ell A. Levine, Assistant Commissioner, Petitioners v. George Fabe, Su-
perintendent of Insurance of Ohio. The motion of the Solicitor General
to dispense with printing the joint appendix is granted.
No. 91-1538. Sandra Jean Smith, Petitioner v. United States. The
motion of petitioner to dispense with printing the joint appendix is
granted.
No. 91-1657. Charlene Leatherman, et al., Petitioners v. Tarrant
County Narcotics Intelligence and Coordination Unit, et al. The motion
of petitioners to permit Richard Gladden to present oral argument pro
hac vice is granted.
No. 91-7873. William Fex, Petitioner v. Michigan. The motion of the
Solicitor General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus cu-
riae and for divided argument is granted.

(JOURNAL)
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1992
991
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-189. Ricky Lee Price, Applicant, v. North Carolina. The appli-
cation for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to the Chief
Justice and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the timely
filing and disposition by this Court of a petition for a writ of certiorari.
Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay termi-
nates automatically. In the event the petition for writ of certiorari is
granted, this stay shall continue pending the issuance of the mandate of
this Court.

(JOURNAL)
MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1992
993
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-5914. James Demouchette, Petitioner, v. James A. Collins,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition
of a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit is denied. Justice Blackmun and Justice Stevens would
grant the application for stay.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1992
995
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
CERTIORARI DENIED
No. 92-5939. James Demouchette, Petitioner, v. Texas. The applica-
tion for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice
Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a
writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Texas is denied.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-201. Bob Slagle, Applicant, v. Louis Terrazas, et al. The appli-
cation for stay presented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the
Court is denied.

(JOURNAL)
TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1992
997
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice. Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. 92-5846. Danny Rae Harris, Petitioner v. James A. Collins, Di-
rector, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
The application for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is granted pending the
disposition by this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should
the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates auto-
matically. In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted,
this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judgment of
this Court.

(JOURNAL)
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1992
999
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice White, Justice Blackmun,
Justice Stevens, Justice O'Connor, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Souter, and Justice Thomas.
ORDER IN PENDING CASE
No. A-242. Rafel Lopez, Jr., Applicant v. Hale County, Texas, et al.
The application for an injunction and stay pending appeal presented to
Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court is denied.
